questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing fatigue and difficulty concentrating at work for the past 2 months. She has hypertension and a 22-year history of Crohn disease. She has been hospitalized and treated for acute exacerbations involving strictures multiple times in the past. She has not had significant gastrointestinal symptoms in over a year. Current medications include mesalamine, thiazide, and bisoprolol. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae and a soft abdomen. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin

9.4 g/dL 


Mean corpuscular volume
112 μm3



Mean corpuscular hemoglobin
37.2 pg/cell


Leukocyte count
8700/mm3



Platelet count
150,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
42 mm/h


Serum



Ferritin
88 ng/mL 


Iron
117 μg/dL 


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
3.2 μU/mL 


Thyroxine
7 μg/dL 


Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Impaired vision in her right eye

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tarry stools, also known as melena, can be a sign of acute or chronic upper gastrointestinal bleeding, both of which can occur in Crohn disease (CD) and result in anemia. However, melena is not typical for CD, especially if there are no signs of acute exacerbation or complications. Moreover, microcytic (MCV < 80 fL) or normocytic (MCV 80–100 fL) anemia is expected in chronic or acute gastrointestinal bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired vision has many etiologies, including neurological disease (e.g., multiple sclerosis), autoimmune disorders (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis), or local problems (e.g., vascular occlusion). Although vitamin B12 deficiency could cause impaired vision, the symptoms would most likely be bilateral since vitamin deficiencies are systemic disorders. In addition, the patient would have most likely exhibited other neurological symptoms before vision loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Unexplained weight gain could be a symptom of autoimmune (Hashimoto) thyroiditis, the most common cause of hypothyroidism. Although Hashimoto thyroiditis can lead to this patient's manifestations and is associated with Crohn disease, megaloblastic anemia is unrelated. If the patient has hypothyroidism, an increased TSH and a decreased T4 if overt, or an increased TSH and a normal T4 if subclinical, would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Dark-colored urine can be due to hemoglobinuria as a result of hemolytic anemia or be caused by disorders that are associated with increased conjugated bilirubin, including hepatic (e.g., hepatitis) or posthepatic conditions (e.g., cholelithiasis). Although this patient has anemia, there are no signs that point to hemolysis (e.g., jaundice or splenomegaly) nor hepatic or posthepatic conditions (e.g., abdominal pain). Furthermore, hemolytic anemia usually manifests as a normocytic (MCV 80–100 fL) rather than megaloblastic anemia (> 100 fL).

E) CORRECT:

Decreased vibratory sensation in patients with vitamin B12 deficiency results from demyelination of the dorsal columns. Insufficient synthesis of fatty acids dependent on vitamin B12 and insufficient myelin production result in subacute combined spinal cord degeneration and neurological symptoms. Further symptoms of dorsal column demyelination include paresthesia, impaired proprioception, loss of tactile sensation, loss of position discrimination, and consequent gait abnormalities (spinal ataxia). Demyelination of the lateral corticospinal tracts can manifest with central paresis.

This patient's vitamin B12 deficiency is likely the result of decreased absorption of the vitamin B12/intrinsic factor complex in the terminal ileum due to mucosal impairment or resection of strictures in Crohn disease.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia, which is most commonly caused by vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized fatigue and numbness of his legs and toes for the past 5 months. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He underwent a partial gastrectomy for peptic ulcer disease 15 years ago. He is a painter. Current medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and glossitis. Sensation to vibration and position is absent over the lower extremities. He has a broad-based gait. The patient sways when he stands with his feet together and closes his eyes. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 4500/mm3, and platelet count is 110,000/mm3. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low serum iron levels are seen in iron deficiency anemia (IDA). Although this patient is anemic, IDA does not explain his neurologic findings. Moreover, reactive thrombocytosis, not thrombocytopenia, would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid are seen in multiple sclerosis (MS), which typically manifests in women 20–50 years old. Patients with MS often experience visual impairment and spastic motor weakness due to demyelination of the spinal cord tracts. The dorsal column of the spinal cord can be involved, causing loss of vibration and proprioception. However, the lack of other characteristic symptoms of MS and absent demographic risk factors make the diagnosis unlikely. Also, MS does not cause anemia.

C) CORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency results in elevated methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels. Vitamin B12 is a coenzyme for methylmalonyl-CoA mutase in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. Thus, if there are insufficient levels of vitamin B12, methylmalonyl-CoA cannot be broken down, leading to an accumulation of MMA and its precursor, propionyl-CoA. These products, along with their associated odd-chain fatty acids, cannot be completely metabolized, which causes neuron damage (due to propionyl-CoA replacing acetyl-CoA in neuronal membranes), demyelination, and consequent neurological manifestations. This patient's vitamin B12 deficiency is likely the result of malabsorption due to partial gastrectomy and the loss of parietal cells that produce intrinsic factor, which is necessary for vitamin B12 absorption in the terminal ileum.

Vitamin B12 deficiency also results in elevated homocysteine levels because vitamin B12 functions as a coenzyme in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine via methionine synthase. Hyperhomocysteinemia is also seen in folate deficiency, which manifests with megaloblastic anemia. Unlike vitamin B12 deficiency, MMA is normal in folate deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Basophilic stippling of RBCs is a nonspecific finding of lead intoxication, which can be seen in painters and manifests with anemia. However, this patient lacks other signs of lead poisoning (e.g., abdominal pain, arthralgias, myalgias, a decline in neurocognitive function, and nephropathy). In addition, lead poisoning would not explain this patient's dorsal column dysfunction.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Pappenheim stain)

The erythrocytes contain purple spots (green overlay), which are consistent with cytoplasmic granules. The large, heavily spotted cell in the center of the right image appears to be a neutrophil. In the center of the left image, there is a normoblast with a prominent nucleus, which is not usually present in peripheral blood and suggests impaired erythropoiesis.

Basophilic stippling describes the appearance of red blood granules, which are mainly composed of aggregating ribosomes. It is characteristic of impaired red blood cell maturation.

E) INCORRECT:

Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test is a common screening test for syphilis. Patients with tertiary syphilis and consequent tabes dorsalis may also present with ataxic gait, sensory abnormalities, and a positive Romberg test. However, this patient lacks the other symptoms of tertiary syphilis (e.g., gummas, meningism) and does not have any clear risk factors (e.g., high-risk sexual behavior). Also, syphilis does not cause anemia.
questions.hint: Anemia, thrombocytopenia, glossitis, signs of dorsal column dysfunction (absent vibration and position sense, positive Romberg test), and a broad-based gait are suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravid woman at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for her initial prenatal visit. She has had generalized fatigue and shortness of breath over the past 2 months. She has also had a tingling sensation in her toes for the past month. Three years ago, she was treated for gonorrhea. She has followed a strict vegan diet since the age of 13 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae and a shiny tongue. Muscle tone and strength are normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to vibration and position is decreased over the upper and lower extremities. When asked to stand, hold her arms in front of her, and close her eyes, she loses her balance and takes a step backward. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While hypocalcemia may cause paresthesias of the distal extremities, it cannot explain this patient's pallor, generalized fatigue, shortness of breath, or glossitis. Also, the neurological findings of sensory loss and positive Romberg test are not consistent with hypocalcemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Folic acid deficiency may occur during pregnancy and can manifest with pallor, generalized fatigue, shortness of breath, glossitis, and macrocytic anemia. However, folic acid deficiency does not result in neurological manifestations (e.g., paresthesia). All pregnant women should receive daily folic acid supplementation in order to prevent neural tube defects in the child.

C) CORRECT:

Conjunctival pallor, fatigue, shortness of breath, and glossitis indicate a nutrient deficiency anemia. Given the concomitant features of subacute combined degeneration (paresthesias, loss of vibratory sensation and proprioception, positive Romberg test), this patient most likely has a vitamin B12 deficiency. A strict vegan diet typically does not have a sufficient amount of vitamin B12and requires supplementation. In addition, the demand for vitamin B12 is higher during pregnancy and lactation.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism may manifest with increased fatigue and macrocytic anemia, however, the absence of other features associated with hypothyroidism (e.g., bradycardia, cold intolerance, dry skin, hyporeflexia, inappropriate maternal or fetal weight gain) suggests a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Penicillin G is indicated for the treatment of syphilis. A history of gonorrhea infection potentially increases the likelihood that the patient has other sexually transmitted diseases like syphilis. Certain forms of neurosyphilis (e.g., tabes dorsalis) can manifest with weakness and neuropathic symptoms (impairment of vibration and position senses). However, the paresthesias in tabes dorsalis are paroxysmal and painful, as opposed to the mild, tingling sensations experienced by this patient, and take years to decades after primary infection to occur. Moreover, tabes dorsalis is characterized by hyporeflexia or areflexia, whereas this patient has brisk peripheral reflexes.

F) INCORRECT:

Pregnant women are at increased risk of iron deficiency anemia (IDA), the most common form of anemia in pregnancy, as a result of plasma expansion and increased production of erythrocytes and should therefore receive low-dose iron supplementation (30 mg/day) starting at the first prenatal visit. IDA may manifest with pallor, generalized fatigue, shortness of breath, and glossitis. However, patients with IDA typically do not display any neurological symptoms; an IDA would not account for this patient's paresthesias, loss of vibratory sensation and proprioception, or the positive Romberg test.
questions.hint: A peripheral blood smear might show hypersegmented neutrophils.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of the gradual onset of fatigue over the past 4 months. He also reports shortness of breath and difficulty concentrating. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 20 years. He does not drink alcohol. He appears pale. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick over the toes bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
8.2 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
108 μm3


Leukocyte count
4500/mm3



Serum



 Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2.6 μU/mL


 Iron
77 μg/dL


 Vitamin B12 (cyanocobalamin)


51 ng/L (N = 170–900)


 Folic acid
13 ng/mL (N = 2–20)


An oral dose of radiolabeled vitamin B12 is administered, followed by an intramuscular injection of nonradioactive vitamin B12. A 24-hour urine sample is collected, and urine vitamin B12 levels are unchanged. The procedure is repeated with the addition of oral intrinsic factor, and 24-hour urine vitamin B12 levels increase. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) have an increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency for multiple reasons, the most significant being metformin use (metformin affects the calcium-dependent ileal absorption of the intrinsic factor-B12 complex). Increased gut transit time due to diabetic autonomic neuropathy may lead to bacterial overgrowth, which can also cause vitamin B12 deficiency. However, there is no data to suggest that patients with pernicious anemia are at an increased risk of developing type 2 DM.

Type 1 DM is more commonly associated with pernicious anemia because both have underlying autoimmune etiologies.

B) INCORRECT:

A history of smoking is a risk factor for colorectal carcinoma and patients with colorectal cancer may present with anemia (due to chronic gastrointestinal (GI) hemorrhage). However, chronic GI hemorrhage typically results in iron-deficiency anemia (microcytic anemia), unlike this man who presents with pernicious anemia (macrocytic anemia). There is currently no clear evidence that patients with pernicious anemia have an increased risk of colorectal carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with celiac disease (CD) may present with symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency as a result of malabsorption. However, a Schilling test in CD would not normalize after the administration of intrinsic factor (IF) because patients typically have normal levels of IF. Moreover, while CD is associated with autoimmune conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis), there is little evidence that pernicious anemia increases the risk for CD.

D) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence to suggest that patients with pernicious anemia are at increased risk of developing de Quervain thyroiditis (i.e., subacute granulomatous thyroiditis), which usually occurs following a viral upper respiratory infection. Patients with pernicious anemia are, however, at increased risk of autoimmune thyroid diseases (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis, Graves disease).

E) CORRECT:

Patients with pernicious anemia are at increased risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma. Approximately 90% of patients with pernicious anemia have chronic atrophic gastritis, which likely accounts for the increased incidence of gastric carcinoma. These patients are also at increased risk for gastric carcinoid tumors as a result of chronic hypergastrinemia, which induces gastric cell hyperplasia.

Patients with newly diagnosed pernicious anemia should undergo a single endoscopic examination and gastric biopsy within 6 months to confirm the presence of atrophic gastritis and rule out dysplastic changes. Endoscopy should be repeated if they develop dyspeptic symptoms. Surveillance endoscopies may also be performed every 3 years in certain high-risk patients (e.g., those with severe columnar metaplasia at the initial biopsy).

The Schilling test can help determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency, but it is no longer routinely used in clinical practice. However, the principles of the test are useful for understanding the pathogenesis of vitamin B12 deficiency.

F) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's history of smoking is a risk factor for pancreatic carcinoma, the presence of pernicious anemia significantly increases his risk for another disease. Studies have shown that there is no statistically significant association between pernicious anemia and pancreatic carcinoma.
questions.hint: Macrocytic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and decreased vitamin B12 levels are consistent with vitamin B12 deficiency. The Schilling test results are consistent with intrinsic factor deficiency, which suggests pernicious anemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of numbness and tingling in his fingers and toes for the past month. He also describes difficulty with balance while walking. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.5 g/dL. Serum homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels are elevated. Peripheral blood smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although sulfa drugs can trigger hemolytic anemia in patients with G6PD deficiency, this patient shows no signs of hemolysis (jaundice, scleral icterus) or G6PD deficiency (Heinz bodies, bite cells) on blood smear. Furthermore, G6PD deficiency would not explain this patient's neurological symptoms or elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Canned food consumption increases the risk of botulism, which manifests with descending flaccid paralysis rather than ataxia and peripheral neuropathy. Botulism also fails to explain this patient's anemia and elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels.

C) CORRECT:

Cyanocobalamin supplementation can prevent cobalamin deficiency (vitamin B12 deficiency), which results in impaired red blood cell (RBC) formation and improper myelination of the nervous system. Vitamin B12 deficiency manifests with megaloblastic anemia, symmetrical peripheral neuropathy, and subacute combined degeneration. A buildup of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (MMA) is also characteristic and helps distinguish vitamin B12 deficiency from folate deficiency, which presents with normal levels of MMA.
Image Description:

Peripheral blood smear (H&E stain; very high magnification)

A large granulocyte (dashed outline) with a hypersegmented nucleus (blue overlay) is surrounded by red blood cells.

The presence of hypersegmented granulocytes in a peripheral blood smear indicates megaloblastic anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Lead-based paint exposure, resulting in lead poisoning, can present with anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and ataxia, which are all seen in this patient. However, lead poisoning would not affect methylmalonic acid or homocysteine levels, nor does this patient's history suggest lead exposure.

E) INCORRECT:

Although pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency can result in anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and elevated homocysteine levels, peripheral blood smear typically shows basophilic stippling of erythrocytes (due to sideroblastic anemia) rather than hypersegmented neutrophils. Furthermore, vitamin B6 deficiency does not explain this patient's elevated methylmalonic acid levels.

F) INCORRECT:

Although folate deficiency manifests with megaloblastic anemia (low Hb, hypersegmented neutrophils) and causes elevated homocysteine levels, which are seen in this patient, neurological manifestations would not be expected. Moreover, methylmalonic acid levels would be normal.
questions.hint: Elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels suggest a specific nutritional deficiency that can be caused by infection with the tapeworm Diphyllobothrium latum.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman with hypothyroidism comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of tingling in her feet and poor balance. Her only medication is levothyroxine. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and an ataxic gait. Proprioception and sense of vibration are decreased in her toes bilaterally. Laboratory studies show macrocytic anemia and normal thyroid hormone levels. Histological evaluation of tissue samples obtained by esophagogastroduodenoscopy reveals atrophic changes of the gastric body and fundus with normal antral mucosa. Which of the following structures is most likely being targeted by antibodies in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Type 1 diabetes mellitus is characterized by the presence of autoantibodies against pancreatic islet cells (e.g., anti-islet cell, anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase). Patients with this condition have an insulin deficiency and may develop peripheral neuropathy due to poor glycemic control. However, the anemia and atrophic gastritis described here are not common features of type 1 DM.

Type 1DM is also associated with other autoimmune conditions such as Hashimoto thyroiditis and/or vitiligo.

B) INCORRECT:

IgG antibodies against deamidated gliadin peptides are characteristic of celiac disease, which can also cause anemia due to iron malabsorption. Laboratory studies would show microcytic anemia rather than the macrocytic anemia seen in this patient. Additionally, neurologic deficits and atrophic gastritis are not consistent with celiac disease.

C) CORRECT:

Pernicious anemia is a common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency and is associated with both anti-parietal cell antibodies and anti-intrinsic factor antibodies. Antibody-mediated destruction of parietal cells leads to decreased intrinsic factor production, resulting in impaired vitamin B12 absorption in the terminal ileum, and subsequent vitamin B12 deficiency, as seen in this patient. Vitamin B12 deficiency classically manifests with macrocytic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and symptoms of subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord.
Image Description:

Gastric acid secretion (HCl) is stimulated by acetylcholine (in response to vagus nerve activity), gastrin (produced by G cells), and histamine (produced by ECL cells in response to vagus nerve activity). The decreasing pH of the gastric juice (due to HCl) acts as a negative feedback mechanism by stimulating D-cells to produce somatostatin, which directly inhibits G-cell activity. As gastric contents enter the duodenum, a variety of hormones are released (summarized at the bottom left of image), each with specific functions.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-smooth muscle antibodies are typically seen in patients with autoimmune hepatitis, which is commonly associated with other autoimmune conditions. Symptomatic patients with this condition may present with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and pruritus. Anemia, neurologic deficits, and atrophic gastritis are not common features of autoimmune hepatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against RBCs are seen in autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). The condition typically manifests with anemia and symptoms of hemolysis (e.g., jaundice). Neurologic deficits, macrocytic anemia, and atrophic gastritis are not common features of hemolytic anemia.
questions.hint: Anemia, gait ataxia, and neurological symptoms (e.g., paresthesias, sensory deficits, hyperreflexia) are signs of vitamin B12 deficiency. This patient's symptoms and EGD findings suggest a diagnosis of pernicious anemia and atrophic gastritis, which is often associated with other autoimmune diseases (particularly vitiligo and Hashimoto thyroiditis).

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of progressive lethargy, shortness of breath, and difficulty concentrating. His friends have told him that he appears pale. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Neurological examination shows reduced sensation to light touch and pinprick in the toes bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
8.2 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
108 μm3


Serum



Vitamin B12 (cyanocobalamin)

51 ng/L (N = 170–900)


Folic acid
13 ng/mL (N = 5.4–18)


An oral dose of radiolabeled vitamin B12 is administered, followed by an intramuscular injection of nonradioactive vitamin B12. A 24-hour urine sample is collected and urine vitamin B12 levels are unchanged. The procedure is repeated with the addition of oral intrinsic factor, and 24-hour urine vitamin B12 levels increase. This patient's findings indicate an increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A history of smoking is a risk factor for colorectal carcinoma, and patients with colorectal cancer may present with anemia (due to chronic GI hemorrhage). However, chronic GI hemorrhage typically results in iron-deficiency anemia (microcytic anemia) rather than pernicious anemia (macrocytic anemia). There is currently no clear evidence that patients with pernicious anemia are at an increased risk of colorectal carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's history of smoking is a risk factor for pancreatic carcinoma, the presence of pernicious anemia significantly increases his risk of another disease. Studies have shown that there is no statistically significant association between pernicious anemia and pancreatic carcinoma.

Chronic pancreatitis, which is a risk factor for pancreatic carcinoma, may also result in vitamin B12 deficiency. However, urinary excretion of radiolabeled B12 would not normalize after repeating the Schilling test with orally administered intrinsic factor because B12 malabsorption in chronic pancreatitis is caused by trypsin deficiency, which results in the impaired breakdown of salivary haptocorrin. Instead, urinary excretion of radiolabelled B12 would normalize only after the ingestion of pancreatic enzymes. Moreover, this patient does not have a history of alcohol use disorder or recurrent abdominal pain, which would suggest chronic pancreatitis.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with pernicious anemia are at increased risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma. Approx. 90% of patients with pernicious anemia have chronic atrophic gastritis, which likely accounts for the increased incidence of gastric carcinoma. These patients are also at increased risk for gastric carcinoid tumor as a result of chronic hypergastrinemia, which induces gastric cell hyperplasia.

The Schilling test can help determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency, but it is no longer routinely used in clinical practice. However, the principles of the test are useful for understanding the pathogenesis of vitamin B12 deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence to suggest that patients with pernicious anemia are at increased risk of developing de Quervain thyroiditis (subacute granulomatous thyroiditis), which usually occurs following a viral upper respiratory infection. Given the autoimmune etiology of their condition, patients with pernicious anemia are at increased risk of developing autoimmune thyroid diseases, including Hashimoto disease and Graves disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with type 2 DM are at increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency for multiple reasons, the most significant being metformin use because metformin affects the calcium-dependent ileal absorption of the intrinsic factor-B12 complex. Increased gut transit time due to diabetic autonomic neuropathy may lead to bacterial overgrowth, which can also cause vitamin B12 deficiency. However, there is no data to suggest that patients with pernicious anemia are at an increased risk of developing type 2 DM.

Atrophic gastritis, which causes pernicious anemia, and type 1 DM are both caused by autoimmune damage. Given this autoimmune association, the median probability that patients with pernicious anemia will have type 1 DM is about 15 times greater than in the general population. However, the onset of type 1 DM, which usually occurs before the age of 20, will typically precede the onset of clinical features of pernicious anemia, which usually appear during adulthood.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with celiac disease may also present with symptoms of B12 deficiency due to malabsorption. However, if the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency was malabsorption due to celiac disease, urinary excretion of radiolabeled B12 would not normalize after repeating the Schilling test with orally administered intrinsic factor (IF). This patient's increased absorption of B12 with oral IF on the Schilling test is diagnostic of pernicious anemia. Because pernicious anemia and celiac disease are both autoimmune diseases, there could theoretically be an association between the two. However, there is currently little evidence to suggest a clear association.
questions.hint: This patient has macrocytic anemia and peripheral neuropathy due to vitamin B12 deficiency. The results of the Schilling test are consistent with intrinsic factor deficiency, which suggests pernicious anemia.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man with Crohn disease is admitted to the hospital because of colicky abdominal pain, constipation, and vomiting. Endoscopy shows a stricture in the terminal ileum. The ileum is surgically resected after endoscopic balloon dilation fails to relieve the obstruction. Three years later, he returns for a follow-up examination. He takes no medications. This patient is most likely to have which of the following physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can manifest with symmetric neurological deficits, including limb weakness and ataxia. Vitamin B12 is a cofactor of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase and methionine synthase, both of which are necessary for proper neuronal function. Because the terminal ileum is the primary site of vitamin B12 absorption, resection of this structure can result in vitamin B12 deficiency unless properly supplemented.

Ileocecal resection can also result in the malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (due to bile acid malabsorption) and micronutrients like magnesium.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyporeflexia and bradycardia are manifestations of severe hypermagnesemia. Causes of hypermagnesemia include decreased elimination (e.g., renal insufficiency), increased intake (e.g., oversupplementation), and increased tissue breakdown (e.g., rhabdomyolysis). Because the terminal ileum is an important site of magnesium absorption, its removal can result in hypomagnesemia rather than hypermagnesemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Gingival swelling and bleeding would be consistent with vitamin C deficiency (scurvy). Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin that functions as an important cofactor in collagen synthesis. This patient is at risk of a malabsorption syndrome but vitamin C absorption is not dependent on the terminal ileum, making significant vitamin C deficiency unlikely in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Pallor with koilonychia is consistent with iron deficiency anemia. Iron is first reduced to its ferrous form (Fe2+) before being absorbed in the duodenum and upper jejunum. This patient is at risk of a malabsorption syndrome but iron absorption is not dependent on the terminal ileum, making these findings unlikely in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Glossitis and pellagra are consistent with niacin deficiency. Niacin is a water-soluble vitamin that is an important coenzyme in redox reactions. This patient is at risk of malabsorption of several vitamins and micronutrients, but niacin absorption is not dependent on the terminal ileum, making significant niacin deficiency unlikely in this patient.
questions.hint: The distal ileum is the primary site of vitamin B12 absorption (in the form of B12-intrinsic factor complex).

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of numbness of her legs and toes for 3 months. She has also had fatigue and occasional shortness of breath for the past 5 months. She is a painter. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. Sensation to vibration and position is absent over the lower extremities. She has a broad-based gait. The patient sways when she stands with her feet together and closes her eyes. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Poliovirus RNA in cerebrospinal fluid is seen in poliomyelitis, which typically presents with asymmetric, flaccid, lower extremities paralysis that is more severe in the proximal muscles. The presence of dorsal column dysfunction, along with the absence of lower extremity paralysis, makes this diagnosis unlikely in this patient. It also would not explain this patient's anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Basophilic stippling is a nonspecific finding found in lead intoxication. This patient is at increased risk of lead poisoning (painter), which causes anemia. However, this patient lacks any other signs of lead poisoning (e.g., abdominal pain, arthralgias, myalgias, a decline in neurocognitive function, and nephropathy). In addition, lead poisoning would not explain this patient's dorsal column dysfunction (absent vibration and position sense, positive Romberg sign).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Pappenheim stain)

The erythrocytes contain purple spots (green overlay), which are consistent with cytoplasmic granules. The large, heavily spotted cell in the center of the right image appears to be a neutrophil. In the center of the left image, there is a normoblast with a prominent nucleus, which is not usually present in peripheral blood and suggests impaired erythropoiesis.

Basophilic stippling describes the appearance of red blood granules, which are mainly composed of aggregating ribosomes. It is characteristic of impaired red blood cell maturation.

C) INCORRECT:

Oligoclonal bands in CSF are seen in multiple sclerosis (MS), which typically presents in women 20–50 years old. Patients with MS often experience visual impairment and spastic motor weakness due to demyelination of the spinal cord tracts. The dorsal column of the spinal cord can be involved, causing loss of vibration and proprioception, as seen in this patient. However, the lack of other characteristic symptoms of MS and absent demographic risk factors make the diagnosis unlikely. Also, MS does not cause anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of a syrinx on spine MRI is seen in syringomyelia, which typically presents with dissociated sensory loss, dysthetic pain, and muscle atrophy in the neck, shoulders, and arms in a cape-like distribution. The expansion of the syrinx can affect the pyramidal tract, leading to spastic paraparesis of the lower extremities. The presence of dorsal column dysfunction, along with the absence of neurological manifestations in the upper extremities, makes this diagnosis unlikely in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test is a common screening test for syphilis. Patients with tertiary syphilis and consequent tabes dorsalis may also present with ataxic gait, sensory abnormalities, and a positive Romberg sign. However, this patient lacks the other symptoms of tertiary syphilis (e.g., gummas, meningism) and does not have any syphilis risk factors (e.g., high-risk sexual behavior). Also, syphilis does not cause anemia.

F) CORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency results in elevated methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels because it is a coenzyme for methylmalonyl-CoA mutase during the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA into succinyl-CoA, which then enters the Krebs cycle. The buildup of MMA and its precursor propionyl-CoA, as well as their associated odd-chain fatty acids, cannot be completely metabolized, which leads to neuron damage (e.g., through propionyl-CoA replacing acetyl-CoA in neuronal membranes). The result is demyelination that leads to neurological manifestations; demyelination of the posterior and lateral columns of the spinal cord results in subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord, which is commonly seen in vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 deficiency also results in elevated homocysteine levels because it is a coenzyme during conversion of homocysteine to methionine via the methionine synthase. Elevated homocysteine increases the risk of cardiovascular disease. Homocysteine can also be elevated in folate deficiency, which also causes megaloblastic anemia, whereas MMA is normal.
questions.hint: The presence of signs of dorsal column dysfunction (vibration and position sense, and a positive Romberg sign) with consequent broad-based gait, in the setting of fatigue, shortness of breath, and pale conjunctivae (due to anemia), is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 1-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after having a seizure. His mother reports that he has become lethargic and does not cry as vigorously anymore. Examination shows muscular hypotonia and hepatomegaly. Arterial blood gas on room air shows metabolic acidosis. Serum studies show elevated levels of methylmalonic acid. A deficiency of which of the following types of enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dehydrogenase enzymes catalyze redox reactions. Common diseases of dehydrogenases include maple syrup urine disease (branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase), pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency, lactate dehydrogenase deficiency, and medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency. Dehydrogenases are not involved in methylmalonyl-CoA conversion.

B) INCORRECT:

Phosphorylase enzymes are crucial to several carbohydrate metabolic pathways where they aid in glycogenolysis by adding inorganic phosphate groups onto their substrates. When deficient (e.g., McArdle disease, Hers disease), affected patients may present with muscle weakness, hypoglycemia, exercise intolerance, hepatomegaly (as seen in this patient), or rhabdomyolysis. However, serum studies will not show any evidence of methylmalonic acidemia as phosphorylase enzymes do not participate in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

C) INCORRECT:

Methionine synthase deficiency will present with elevated serum levels of homocysteine (absent in this patient) and methylmalonyl-CoA. A cystathionine synthase deficiency will also result in homocystinuria and affected patients will be clinically similar to patients with a methionine synthase deficiency. Affected patients may present with myopia, ectopia lentis, intellectual disability, skeletal anomalies (resembling Marfan syndrome), and thromboembolic events, none of which are seen in this patient. This patient's presentation and serum analysis are more indicative of a different enzyme deficiency that causes methylmalonic acidemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Carboxylase enzymes transfer carbon dioxide groups and require biotin as a cofactor. Notable examples include pyruvate carboxylase (carbohydrate metabolism), acetyl-CoA carboxylase (fatty acid synthesis), and propionyl-CoA carboxylase (odd-chain fatty acid degradation). Although deficiency of enzymes of this type can lead to organic acidemias, they are not involved in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydroxylase enzymes add a hydroxyl group (−OH) to their substrate. In the liver, the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. A defect in PAH is the hallmark of phenylketonuria (PKU). Affected patients may present with seizures, as seen in this patient. However, eczema, psychomotor retardation, blue eyes, and light pale hair are more characteristic of PKU. Hydroxylases do not participate in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

F) CORRECT:

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is the enzyme that catalyzes the isomerization of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. A deficiency of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, or its cofactor vitamin B12, will result in accumulation of methylmalonic acid in the serum. Methylmalonic acidemia in neonates typically presents with lethargy, vomiting, dehydration, failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, hypotonia, and encephalopathy. Affected patients are at risk of severe morbidity if disease is left untreated.
questions.hint: Elevated levels of methylmalonic acid in the presence of metabolic acidosis are suggestive of methylmalonic acidemia, which is most commonly caused by a deficiency of an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of developmental delay and intellectual disability. He has been admitted to the hospital twice in the past 6 months because of a cerebral venous thrombosis and a pulmonary embolism, respectively. He is at 10th percentile for weight and 95th percentile for height. Physical examination shows bilateral downward and inward subluxation of the lenses. He has a high-arched palate and kyphosis. Laboratory studies show increased serum concentration of 5-methyltetrahydrofolate. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient's serum?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased cysteine concentrations may be seen in patients with homocystinuria secondary to a deficiency to cystathionine synthase. Although patients with cystathionine synthase deficiency would present similarly to this patient, his homocystinuria is likely instead secondary to methionine synthase deficiency. This is indicated by his elevated serum levels of 5-methyltetrahydrofolate. Cysteine levels would be normal in patients with methionine synthase deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

An increased s-adenosylhomocysteine concentration would not be expected in patients with homocysteinuria secondary to a defect in methionine synthase. S-adenosylhomocysteine is a downstream metabolite in this metabolic pathway, meaning a decreased (not increased) serum concentration would be expected in this case.

C) CORRECT:

Decreased methionine concentration is characteristic of homocystinuria secondary to methionine synthase deficiency. Note that homocystinuria can also result from cystathionine synthase deficiency, however, this would cause elevated rather than decreased serum levels of methionine. Homocystinuria secondary to methionine synthase deficiency also results in elevated serum 5-methyltetrahydrofolate. Alternatively, this is not true in patients with cystathionine synthase deficiency.
Image Description:

Methionine is an essential amino acid that generates sulfur-containing amino acids (i.e., cysteine, homocysteine, and taurine) as well as S-adenosyl methionine (SAM), a coenzyme of several methylation reactions, through the methionine cycle.

ATP donates adenosine to methionine, converting it to SAM. SAM then loses its methyl group to form S-adenosylhomocysteine, which loses its adenosine molecule to form homocysteine. Homocysteine can then enter three pathways: It can be converted to succinyl CoA (which enters the citric acid cycle), cysteine (from which taurine is generated; not shown here), or back to methionine. Methionine synthase catalyzes the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine in the presence of vitamin B12 and N5-methyltetrahydrofolate (N5-methyl-THF).

D) INCORRECT:

Increased propionyl-CoA concentration would not be expected in homocystinuria secondary to a defect in methionine synthase, as seen in this patient's case. Propionyl-CoA is a downstream metabolite in this metabolic pathway, meaning a decreased (not increased) serum concentration would be expected in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased cystathionine concentrations may be seen in patients with homocystinuria secondary to a deficiency to cystathionine synthase. Although patients with cystathionine synthase deficiency would present similarly to this patient, his homocystinuria is likely instead secondary to methionine synthase deficiency. This is indicated by his elevated serum levels of 5-methyltetrahydrofolate. Cystathionine levels would be normal in patients with methionine synthase deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient presents with intellectual disability, a history of thromboembolic events, Marfanoid habitus (tall stature, high-arched palate), and lens subluxation, all of which are concerning for the diagnosis of homocystinuria. Homocystinuria can be caused by a deficiency in one of two different enzymes. This patient's elevated serum 5-methyltetrahydrofolate confirms one of these two deficiencies.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of intermittent episodes of upper abdominal pain after eating. The pain does not radiate and is occasionally associated with bloating and nausea. She has not had changes in appetite or in bowel habits. She also reports worsening fatigue and a pins-and-needles sensation in her hands and feet for the last 3 months. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus well controlled with an insulin pump. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. BMI is 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. The abdomen is soft and there is no tenderness. On neurologic examination, sensation to pinprick is decreased in the feet bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.6 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
111 μm3


Leukocyte count
6800/mm3



Hemoglobin A1c
5.9%


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peptic ulcer disease (PUD), which is most commonly caused by Helicobacter pylori infection, can manifest with postprandial abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. Although gastrointestinal bleeding in PUD may also cause anemia, it is typically normocytic (due to acute blood loss) or microcytic (resulting from iron deficiency). Vitamin B12 deficiency is not a feature of PUD.

B) CORRECT:

Dyspepsia and features of vitamin B12 deficiency in a patient with an autoimmune disease (type 1 diabetes mellitus) suggest autoimmune metaplastic atrophic gastritis (AMAG). Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells in AMAG causes achlorhydria and hypergastrinemia, which can progress to hyperplasia of enterochromaffin-like cells and subsequent carcinoid tumors. Furthermore, autoantibodies against intrinsic factor lead to vitamin B12 malabsorption and pernicious anemia. AMAG is also associated with an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy with biopsy is the diagnostic test of choice for atrophic gastritis. Vitamin B12 replacement therapy is indicated for patients with vitamin B12 deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) can manifest with abdominal discomfort and vitamin B12 deficiency (due to bacterial utilization of vitamins). However, other features of SIBO, such as diarrhea, steatorrhea, flatulence, and weight loss are absent in this patient. Moreover, this patient does not have typical risk factors for SIBO, such as an anatomic cause (e.g., short bowel syndrome, inflammatory bowel disease) or a motility disorder (e.g., irritable bowel syndrome). While poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus can cause intestinal motility disorders, this patient's normal HbA1c indicates good glycemic control

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic pancreatitis can manifest with postprandial abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. Chronic pancreatitis can further lead to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, which reduces the uptake of the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 complex in the terminal ileum. However, this patient has no risk factors for chronic pancreatitis, such as heavy alcohol use, pancreatic duct obstruction, or tobacco use, making another diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Gastroparesis can manifest with postprandial abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea and is most commonly caused by autonomic neuropathy due to poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus. This patient's sensory loss (decreased sensation to pinprick) could be caused by diabetic neuropathy. However, her HbA1c is within normal limits, indicating good glycemic control. Furthermore, diabetes mellitus does not cause macrocytic anemia.
questions.hint: Macrocytic anemia in combination with symmetrical peripheral neuropathy raises suspicion for vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man with a history of type 1 diabetes presents with lower-extremity paresthesias. He has not had any prior surgeries.
On examination, he has conjunctival pallor, scattered areas of hypopigmentation, and diminished vibration and cutaneous sensation of the lower extremities in a boot-like distribution.
Laboratory testing yields the following notable results:



Patient value
Reference range


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
6.7
4.3–5.6


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
9.7
13.5–17.5



Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
103
80–100



Leukocyte count (per mm3)
4000
4500–11,000


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
1.5
0.5–4.7


Results of routine chemical tests, albumin levels, iron studies, and liver function tests are within normal ranges.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Whipple disease is a rare, systemic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei and primarily causes malabsorption. Weight loss, diarrhea, joint pain, and arthritis are common presenting symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and signs are consistent with vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency is a common cause of macrocytic anemia and, in advanced cases, pancytopenia. Neurologic sequelae from vitamin B12 deficiency include paresthesias, peripheral neuropathy, and demyelination of the corticospinal tract and dorsal columns. Vitamin B12 deficiency has also been linked to psychiatric disorders, including depression, dementia, and, in rare instances, psychosis.

Measurement of metabolites such as methylmalonic acid and homocysteine has been shown to be more diagnostic of vitamin B12 deficiency than measurement of serum B12 levels alone.

Scattered areas of hypopigmentation are most suggestive of a diagnosis of vitiligo. In a patient with type 1 diabetes and vitiligo, the most likely cause of vitamin B12 deficiency is pernicious anemia. Elevated antiparietal-cell antibodies and anti-intrinsic factor antibodies, along with chronic atrophic gastritis on endoscopy, are also found in patients with pernicious anemia.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with lower-extremity paresthesias and a macrocytic anemia is pernicious anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a genetic syndrome that typically manifests with weakness of the foot and lower-leg muscles, which may result in foot drop and a high-stepped gait with frequent tripping or falls. Foot deformities, such as high arches and hammer toes, are also characteristic.

D) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease would be unusual in the absence of abdominal pain, diarrhea, or signs of malabsorption on laboratory evaluation. Although celiac disease could manifest with an iron-deficiency anemia, this would be microcytic.

E) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis is a cause of a sensory-predominant peripheral neuropathy but is not typically associated with type 1 diabetes or macrocytosis.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man who required an ileocecectomy 3 years ago for Crohn disease recently noted mild abdominal pain and an increase in loose stools. Colonoscopy shows disease recurrence at the anastomosis, with involvement of more than 10 cm of the neoterminal ileum. There is no family history of hypercoagulability.
For which deficiency is this patient most at risk?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chromium deficiency is rare and is not associated with isolated terminal ileal Crohn disease. Patients on long-term total parenteral nutrition without chromium supplementation may develop impaired glucose tolerance, weight loss, and confusion.

B) CORRECT:

Patients who have had resections of the terminal ileum and those who currently have disease affecting the terminal ileum are at increased risk for developing deficiency of vitamin B12 . Gastric acid and pancreatic enzymes liberate vitamin B12 from animal proteins, after which it combines with intrinsic factor produced by gastric parietal cells and is absorbed in the terminal ileum.

Vitamin B12 deficiency causes a macrocytic anemia and neurologic symptoms. The hematologic and neurologic signs occur independently. Patients with vitamin B12 deficiency may maintain a normal hematocrit and mean corpuscular volume even if they do not receive folic acid. Having a high index of suspicion is important because the extent of the neurologic impairment is determined by the duration of symptoms before treatment is initiated. Vitamin B12 deficiency can be difficult to diagnose because both false-negative and false-positive values are common. Measurements of serum vitamin B12 may not reliably detect deficiency. Measurement of serum homocysteine and/or methylmalonic acid should be used to confirm deficiency in asymptomatic high-risk patients with low-normal levels of vitamin B12 .

Oral administration of high-dose vitamin B12 (1 to 2 mg daily) is as effective as intramuscular administration in correcting the deficiency.

Key learning point: The most common deficiency syndrome following surgical resection of the terminal ileum in patients with Crohn disease is deficiency of vitamin B12 .

C) INCORRECT:

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency can lead to symptoms of beriberi, a major nutritional complication of bariatric surgery. Nervous system symptoms include weight loss, emotional lability, impaired sensory perception, weakness, and pain in the limbs. Cardiovascular symptoms include edema, irregular heart rate, and high-output cardiac failure. Thiamine deficiency may occur concurrently with other B-vitamin deficiencies. Thiamine and riboflavin deficiency are not associated with terminal ileal disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency may result from a poor diet or from conditions that cause malabsorption from the intestine. Symptoms include sore throat, scaly dermatitis, stomatitis, and normochromic normocytic anemia. Thiamine and riboflavin deficiency are not associated with terminal ileal disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of biotin can develop after gastrectomy but is rare. Initially, biotin deficiency affects the skin and hair. As it becomes more severe, patients may develop mental status changes, depression, myalgias, hyperesthesias, and paresthesias, along with nausea, vomiting, and anorexia.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents with fatigue and difficulty with balance. He has a 5-year history of Addison disease and primary hypothyroidism. He does not have diarrhea, bloating, or abdominal discomfort. He takes hydrocortisone, fludrocortisone, and levothyroxine. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His mother had adrenal insufficiency and type 1 diabetes.
On examination, his blood pressure is 124/90 mm Hg and his heart rate is 70 beats per minute. He appears pale. Vibratory sense is diminished in his lower extremities.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Glucose (mg/dL)
100
70–100



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.2
13.5–17.5



Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
109
80–100


Hematocrit (%)
32.0
41.0–53.0


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
3.6
0.5–4.7


Iron (μg/dL)
70
30–160


Ferritin (ng/mL)
110
30–300


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
31
30–80


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Untreated hypothyroidism is unlikely in this scenario, because the thyroid-stimulating hormone level is not elevated.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type II (APS II), which is characterized by autoimmune primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease) and autoimmune thyroid disease, with or without type 1 diabetes. Patients with APS II are at increased risk for developing pernicious anemia, which leads to anemia and neurologic findings, such as ataxia. Patients with pernicious anemia have low hemoglobin and hematocrit levels, low vitamin B12 levels, elevated methylmalonic acid levels, and hypersegmented neutrophils and macrocytosis on a peripheral blood smear. The neurologic features of pernicious anemia include ataxia, decreased vibratory sense, loss of position sense, and numbness and tingling. Pernicious anemia is treated with vitamin B12 supplementation.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with polyglandular syndrome type II who presents with anemia, ataxia, pallor, and decreased vibratory sense is pernicious anemia, which is characterized by the presence of positive intrinsic factor antibodies, a low vitamin B12 level, and an elevated methylmalonic acid level.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type II are at risk for developing celiac disease, but this is characterized by iron deficiency, vitamin D deficiency, and positive transglutaminase antibodies.

D) INCORRECT:

Cold agglutinin disease can be characterized by mild macrocytosis and hemolytic anemia, but patients usually have no neurologic symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Myelodysplasia is unlikely; patients with myelodysplasia do not typically have ataxia.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old woman reports a 4-month history of paresthesias in the tips of her fingers and toes, which she attributes to old age. She has a history of osteoarthritis of the hands and knees (for which she takes acetaminophen as needed) and heartburn (for which she takes omeprazole or famotidine intermittently) but is otherwise in good health. Her weight has been stable for many years, she eats a reasonably balanced diet, and she consumes no alcohol.
Her vital signs are normal, and examination of her head, neck, chest, and abdomen is unremarkable. Neurologic examination identifies decreased vibratory and position sense in the feet, but sensation to pinprick and muscle strength are intact.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
9000
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12.2
12.0–16.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
160,000
150,000–350,000


Reticulocyte count (% red cells)
0.7
0.5–2.5


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
97
80–100



Vitamin B12 (pg/mL)
260
>250



Folate, serum (ng/mL)
15.0
3.1–17.5


Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
320
100–190


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
5.4
3.8–6.4


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
1.2
0.5–4.7


A peripheral-blood smear shows mild anisocytosis but is otherwise normal.
Which one of the following next steps in evaluation is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Check for the presence of antiparietal-cell antibodies
Check for the presence of anti-intrinsic factor antibodies
Measure serum methylmalonic acid and homocysteine levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Parietal-cell antibodies are markers for pernicious anemia, an autoimmune disease in which a lack of intrinsic factor causes vitamin B12 malabsorption. However, negative tests for these antibodies would not necessarily exclude vitamin B12 malabsorption: Some older patients with low serum vitamin B12 levels have reduced ability to liberate vitamin B12 from food (a condition called protein-bound vitamin B12 malabsorption); inadequate gastric acidity is thought to predispose to this condition. In a patient with a borderline serum vitamin B12 level, the deficiency should first be confirmed by methylmalonic acid and homocysteine measurements; tests for pernicious anemia could follow, if deficiency is confirmed.

B) INCORRECT:

Folate deficiency is not generally associated with peripheral neuropathic signs and symptoms (although some cases have been described). Although the erythrocyte folate level is a better indicator of folate stores than the serum folate level, erythrocyte folate testing is usually reserved for cases in which serum folate levels are in the low-normal range and clinical suspicion for folate deficiency is high. In this well-nourished, nonalcoholic patient whose serum folate level is in the high-normal range, measurement of erythrocyte folate is unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Intrinsic-factor antibodies are markers for pernicious anemia, an autoimmune disease in which a lack of intrinsic factor causes vitamin B12 malabsorption. However, negative tests for these antibodies would not necessarily exclude vitamin B12 malabsorption: Some older patients with low serum vitamin B12 levels have reduced ability to liberate vitamin B12 from food (a condition called protein-bound vitamin B12 malabsorption); inadequate gastric acidity is thought to predispose to this condition. In a patient with a borderline serum vitamin B12 level, the deficiency should first be confirmed by methylmalonic acid and homocysteine measurements; tests for pernicious anemia could follow, if deficiency is confirmed.

D) INCORRECT:

Nerve conduction testing could support a clinically suspected diagnosis of neuropathy but would not confirm a specific cause.

E) CORRECT:

Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency is a cause of peripheral neurologic signs and symptoms reflecting involvement of the dorsal and lateral spinal columns. Patients may develop neurologic symptoms before developing anemia or macrocytosis. When the serum vitamin B12 level falls within the borderline range (between 200 and 300 pg/mL), further testing is required to document deficiency. Methylmalonic acid and homocysteine levels are elevated in patients with vitamin B12 deficiency; measurement of these levels is recommended to confirm vitamin B12 deficiency in patients with borderline vitamin B12 blood levels. The homocysteine level — but not the methylmalonic acid level — is elevated in folate deficiency.

Key learning point: In a patient with parasthesias, decreased vibratory and position sense in the feet, a borderline-low vitamin B12 level, and a high-normal folate level, the most appropriate next test is measurement of serum methylmalonic acid and homocysteine levels.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents with new numbness and tingling in both feet. Her history includes long-standing type 2 diabetes (well controlled on metformin 1000 mg twice daily), hypertension (treated with lisinopril), and gastroesophageal reflux disease (treated with omeprazole 40 mg daily). She does not have a previous history of neuropathy. Her review of systems is otherwise negative.
Her heart rate is 72 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 110/64 mm Hg. She has diminished vibratory and position sense in both feet and mild hyperreflexia on testing of ankle reflexes.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
4500
4500–11,000



Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
110
80–100


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.0
12.0–16.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
250,000
150,000–350,000


Reticulocyte count (% red cells)
1.0
0.5–2.5


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.8
0.6–1.1


Which one of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of macrocytosis, anemia, and neurologic findings suggests vitamin B12 deficiency. The neurologic manifestations of B12 deficiency include involvement of the dorsal spinal columns (with impairment of position sense and vibratory sense) and the lateral spinal columns. Early in the clinical course, involvement of upper motor neurons in the lateral spinal columns may cause hyperreflexia.

Long-term use of metformin and long-term use of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) have been associated with development of low vitamin B12 levels; the presumed mechanism is interference with B12 absorption. Although the incidence of symptomatic B12 deficiency among long-term users of these medications remains unclear, a vitamin B12 level should be checked in this patient.

Key learning point: Long-term use of metformin or a proton pump inhibitor has been associated with development of low levels of vitamin B12 .

B) INCORRECT:

Diabetic neuropathy could explain new-onset distal sensory symptoms, but this peripheral neuropathy usually presents with hyporeflexia (not hyperreflexia). Additionally, diabetes does not typically cause macrocytic anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

In otherwise healthy people, inadequate dietary intake alone almost never causes vitamin B12 deficiency, except in strict vegetarians.

D) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic neuropathy could explain new-onset distal sensory symptoms, but this peripheral neuropathy usually presents with hyporeflexia (not hyperreflexia). Additionally, paraneoplastic effects of malignancy typically do not cause macrocytic anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia is invariably associated with reticulocytosis (unless a patient has an additional condition that suppresses hematopoiesis). This patient has no reticulocytosis, and none of her medications typically cause drug-induced hemolysis.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, epigastric discomfort, abdominal bloating, and tingling in his hands that has progressed during the past 6 months. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide, methyldopa, and famotidine. He does not smoke, drinks alcohol only rarely, and has no dietary restrictions. He recently suffered a mechanical fall, which he attributed to loss of balance.
The patient’s vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, he appears pale, and his tongue is smooth and swollen. His lungs are clear, and his cardiovascular examination is normal. His abdomen is soft, with mild-to-moderate tenderness in the epigastrium, without organomegaly. Sensation of light touch is reduced in his hands and feet. His Romberg test is abnormal.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
7.5
13.5–17.5


Hematocrit (%)
20.0
41.0–53.0


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
3300
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
88,000
150,000–350,000


Mean corpuscular volume (per μm3)
103
80–100


Reticulocyte count (% red cells)
0.8
0.5–2.5


Bilirubin (mg/dL)
2.4
0.3–1.0


Direct bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.4
0.1–0.3


Levels of serum electrolytes, aspartate and alanine aminotransferases, alkaline phosphatase, serum iron, and ferritin are normal, as are urinalysis results, renal function, total iron-binding capacity, and prothrombin and partial-thromboplastin times.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methyldopa, one of this patient’s medications, may cause a hemolytic anemia but is not associated with neurologic disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Myelodysplastic syndrome can be a cause for pancytopenia but is not typically associated with paresthesias or loss of balance.

C) INCORRECT:

Babesiosis can range from subclinical to fulminant illness, characterized by severe hemolytic anemia and multisystem failure. The peripheral smear may show evidence of hemolysis (basophilic stippling, hemolysis of red cells, nucleated red cells, and schistocytes), but it is not a cause of macrocytosis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms are attributable to severe anemia. The differential diagnosis of macrocytosis with pancytopenia includes infections (e.g., tickborne disease and HIV), vitamin deficiencies (vitamin B12 or folate), certain medications, and autoimmune, neoplastic, and paraneoplastic causes. Glossitis is more often associated with vitamin B12 deficiency than with other conditions in the differential diagnosis. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with a macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils, consistent with megaloblastic anemia. There is increased hemolysis related to premature destruction of red cells, which is associated with laboratory findings such as an increased bilirubin level. Once vitamin B12 deficiency is confirmed, further workup should be aimed at establishing the etiologic factors. The causes of vitamin B12 deficiency include pernicious anemia, Helicobacter pylori infection, chronic gastritis, and long-term use of acid-suppressive therapy.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a sore tongue, macrocytosis, pancytopenia, and paresthesias is vitamin B12 deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism typically causes macrocytosis and mild anemia.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old man with a medical history of hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and osteoarthritis is evaluated for frequent falls. He has chronic hip and knee pain, but this is not recently worse. He has mild and stable shortness of breath but reports no headaches, chest pain, dizziness or lightheadedness, abdominal pain, diarrhea, or weight loss. He takes lisinopril, uses an ipratropium inhaler, and takes acetaminophen as needed for joint pain.
He lives alone and does his own activities of daily living, including shopping for groceries and cooking (with no weight loss). He does not smoke or consume alcohol.
His vital signs include a normal temperature, a heart rate of 78 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 127/75 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while he is breathing ambient air. Cranial nerve, oropharyngeal, neck, cardiac, and abdominal examinations are normal. His lung examination is notable for mildly diminished breath sounds diffusely but no wheezes or rhonchi. He does not have leg edema, and his leg strength is normal. Foot examination is notable for symmetrically diminished sensation to light touch and impaired vibration sense.

Which one of the following vitamins and minerals is most likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency can cause anemia, but it would be microcytic instead of macrocytic.

B) INCORRECT:

Thiamine deficiency can cause neurologic symptoms, including a peripheral neuropathy, but would not cause a macrocytic anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency causes coagulopathy and a tendency to bleed, not a neuropathy or macrocytic anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Folate deficiency can also cause a macrocytic anemia, but neurologic findings on examination are more common with vitamin B12 deficiency than folate deficiency.

E) CORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency should be suspected in this patient because of the physical examination finding of neuropathy (diminished sensation to light touch and vibration in the feet) and the macrocytic anemia. This older adult who lives alone and performs all his own activities of daily living, including grocery shopping and cooking, is at risk for poor nutrition, which may predispose him to developing vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause a variety of neuropsychiatric symptoms, including paresthesias and gait problems, and classically causes subacute combined degeneration of the dorsal and lateral columns of the spinal cord.

Key learning point: Macrocytic anemia in the setting of peripheral neuropathy should raise concern for vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old woman with Alzheimer disease who resides in a nursing home is referred for evaluation of a new anemia. The staff noticed that she has been more lethargic and less interactive during the past 3 months, and a fingerstick test conducted there revealed a hemoglobin level of 7.1 g/dL (reference range, 12.0–16.0).
On examination, the patient appears pale. She is alert and oriented to name and place but is confused about the year. Neurologic examination reveals a shuffling, broad-based gait and diminished sensation to light touch and pinprick.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
6.8
12.0–16.0



Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
112
80–100


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
4200
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
140,000
150,000–350,000


Reticulocyte count (per mm3)
23,000
20,000–80,000


Haptoglobin (mg/dL)
30

Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
185
100–190



Vitamin B12 (pg/mL)
262
>250


Urine testing for free hemoglobin and hemosiderin is negative. A peripheral blood smear is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following additional laboratory tests should this patient undergo next?

choices.text: Flow cytometry for CD55 and CD59 proteins

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A direct Coombs test is used to rule out autoimmune hemolytic anemia, but this diagnosis is unlikely in this patient. Her peripheral blood smear shows no spherocytes, and there is no laboratory evidence of hemolysis (her lactate dehydrogenase and haptoglobin levels are normal).

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s peripheral blood smear shows many large, oval-shaped erythrocytes (macrocytic anemia), and the single neutrophil has at least six visible lobes (neutrophil hypersegmentation). Clinical evaluation of macrocytic anemia begins with evaluation of the most likely causes, such as nutritional deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12 deficiency), excess alcohol use, myelodysplastic syndrome, and (more rarely) severe hypothyroidism.

Vitamin B12 deficiency has many causes, including diseases of the ileum (e.g., inflammatory bowel conditions such as Crohn disease), gastrectomy, pernicious anemia (related to autoantibodies against intrinsic factor), excess alcohol use, and lack of adequate dietary intake (e.g., because of adherence to a strict vegan diet). Mild or subclinical manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are common in older adults and may stem from one or more of the aforementioned factors, as well as from other factors that contribute to vitamin B12 malabsorption, such as gastric atrophy, intestinal overgrowth related to antibiotic treatment, and long-term use of certain medications (histamine-2-receptor antagonists, proton pump inhibitors, and metformin).

In vitamin B12 deficiency, there is an increase in red blood cell turnover in the marrow, and the lactate dehydrogenase level is often at the upper limit of normal or slightly elevated. Although folate deficiency is uncommon now (given the fortification of many foods with folic acid), it can coexist with vitamin B12 deficiency, so testing for both is important when vitamin B12 deficiency is suspected.

A vitamin B12 level <200 pg/mL has a specificity of 95% to 100% for vitamin B12 deficiency, whereas a vitamin B12 level >300 pg/mL (normal range) makes the diagnosis of vitamin B12 deficiency very unlikely. When a borderline result of 200 to 300 pg/mL is identified in a patient with macrocytic anemia (as in this patient), a diagnosis of vitamin B12 deficiency is possible, and further testing should be undertaken. Serum levels of biologic intermediates of vitamin B12 production (e.g., methylmalonic acid and homocysteine) can be more sensitive for vitamin B12 deficiencythan serum levels of vitamin B12 are. Notably, only the homocysteine level is elevated in patients with folate deficiency. Treatment of vitamin B12 deficiency normalizes these metabolic intermediates.

Because folate can correct the marrow defect from vitamin B12 deficiency, many older patients come to medical attention with neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency, including worsening cognition, balance problems, gait problems, numbness, and paresthesias. Folate deficiency is not generally associated with neurologic signs and symptoms.

Key learning point: In a patient with a severe macrocytic anemia associated with neurologic findings, an elevated serum methylmalonic acid level is very specific for identifying vitamin B12 deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

The absence of hemolysis, microangiopathic changes, and red-cell agglutination on this patient’s blood smear also rule out the possibility of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura and cold agglutinin disease. Thus, there is no basis for measuring the ADAMTS13 enzyme level or cold agglutinin titer in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

The absence of hemolysis, microangiopathic changes, and red-cell agglutination on this patient’s blood smear also rule out the possibility of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura and cold agglutinin disease. Thus, there is no basis for measuring the ADAMTS13 enzyme level or cold agglutinin titer in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry for the glycophosphatidylinositol-linked proteins CD55 and CD59 is used to test for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, but this patient does not have reticulocytosis, an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level, or any other signs or symptoms of this condition.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents for follow-up of her ileal Crohn disease, which was diagnosed 5 years ago and has been poorly controlled because of difficulty with treatment adherence. She reports having occasional abdominal pain and daily diarrhea but no fevers, headache, joint pain, or swelling. She has lost about 2.7 kg since her last office visit 6 months ago.
On physical examination, she is thin and pale, with conjunctival and palatal pallor. She has a temperature of 37.2°C, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 105/68 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. Her heart and lung sounds are unremarkable. Her abdomen is thin, soft, and nontender with no hepatomegaly.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
6600
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
7.1
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
20.9
36.0–46.0


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
103
80–100


Platelet count (per mm3)
340,000
150,000–350,000


Neutrophils (%)
42
40–70


Lymphocytes (%)
