Which of the following clinical features is most likely to be associated with this patient’s anemia?

choices.text: Memory loss and irritability related to demyelination of the frontal cortex
Erythematous rash surrounding the mouth and anus
Increased bruising, gum bleeding, and development of petechiae
Ataxia and paresthesias related to demyelination of the lateral and dorsal spinal cord

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In addition to signs and symptoms of anemia, the most common manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are neurologic changes. The most common and early neurologic changes are caused by myelin degeneration of the dorsal and lateral spinal columns, leading to paresthesias and ataxia as a result of a loss of vibration and position sense. This neuropathy, which affects the legs more frequently than the arms, may progress to severe weakness, spasticity, and clonus. Irritability, memory loss, and cerebellar ataxia (resulting from demyelination of the central nervous system) can also occur but are much less common than paresthesias and ataxia.

B) INCORRECT:

Jaundiced skin and sclerae would be seen in patients with hemolysis as an explanation for their anemia. There is no indication from this patient’s history or laboratory results that she has an active hemolytic process.

C) INCORRECT:

An erythematous rash involving the perioral and perianal areas is most commonly associated with zinc deficiency, not vitamin B12 deficiency. Although children with poorly controlled inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) can develop zinc deficiency, they are typically asymptomatic and do not present with acrodermatitis (a feature seen in infants with genetic defects in zinc absorption). Furthermore, zinc deficiency does not result in a macrocytic anemia (which this patient has), and rash is not typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased bruising, bleeding gums, and petechiae are typically seen in patients with vitamin C deficiency, not vitamin B12 deficiency. These symptoms are the hallmark of scurvy.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has a low hemoglobin level and elevated mean corpuscular volume, consistent with a macrocytic anemia. These laboratory results, together with the patient’s uncontrolled gastrointestinal disease, raise concern for vitamin B12 deficiency.

To understand vitamin B12 deficiency, one must consider the many steps required for vitamin B12 absorption: (1) adequate ingestion of vitamin B12 through diet; (2) separation of vitamin B12 from other food proteins in the stomach by gastric acid and pepsin, and then binding of vitamin B12 to R factors in the stomach; (3) separation of vitamin B12 from R factors by pancreatic proteases, followed by binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor (IF); (4) production of IF by the stomach to allow for absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum; and (5) binding of the IF-B12 complex to receptors in the ileum, resulting in absorption.

This patient’s vitamin B12 deficiency was likely caused by diminished absorption of vitamin B12 as a result of intestinal inflammation secondary to Crohn disease with ileal involvement.

Key learning point: In addition to signs and symptoms of anemia, the major clinical manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency in a patient with chronic gastrointestinal disease are neurologic changes, including ataxia and paresthesias related to demyelination of the lateral and dorsal spinal cord.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents for her routine physical examination. She has not had any major illnesses or injuries since her last visit 2 years ago and is working full-time as an occupational therapist. She reports no chest pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, or joint pain during exercise but notes that, during the past several weeks, she has felt more fatigued than usual during her regular fitness class. She is otherwise well and has no other complaints.
Her menses are regular without prolonged or heavy bleeding. She says that she eats a healthy diet and that, about 6 years ago, she began adhering to a strict vegan diet because of concerns about animal cruelty. She typically eats a bowl of iron-fortified cereal for breakfast and has orange juice with it. She does not take a multivitamin.
On examination, her vital signs are normal. Her head and neck examination is normal, and she has no lymphadenopathy. Her lungs are clear, and her cardiovascular examination is normal. She has no abdominal tenderness or organomegaly.
Which one of the following laboratory studies is most likely to reveal the underlying cause of this patient’s fatigue?

choices.text: Iron level, total iron-binding capacity, and ferritin level

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Strict vegan diets — which eliminate all animal products, including milk products and eggs — have become increasingly popular. Although these diets may be healthier than a typical diet (because they contain less saturated fat and more servings of fruit and vegetables), extra care must be taken to ensure adequate intake of vitamins and nutrients, including calcium, vitamin D, vitamin B12, iron, and protein. Folate intake is typically adequate in vegan diets.

People may gradually develop anemia after switching to a vegan diet and may be asymptomatic or have only subtle symptoms, such as fatigue. The most common cause of anemia in people consuming a strict vegan diet without vitamin supplementation is vitamin B12 deficiency. Of note, patients with vitamin B12 deficiency may present with neurologic symptoms rather than anemia, because adequate intake of folate (present in many food items) may partially correct the anemia that would be expected with vitamin B12 deficiency.

Zinc deficiency would be less likely to cause fatigue than vitamin B12 deficiency in a patient not regularly taking vitamin B12 supplementation.

Key learning point: Fatigue in a patient who eats a strict vegan diet is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s daily consumption of iron-fortified cereal combined with vitamin C (which can improve bioavailability) should make iron deficiency a less likely cause for anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

The most common cause of anemia in people consuming a strict vegan diet without vitamin supplementation is vitamin B12 deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Her reported consumption of orange juice should at least partially reduce her risk of vitamin D deficiency. Symptoms of severe vitamin D deficiency include bone and muscle pain.

E) INCORRECT:

The most common cause of anemia in people consuming a strict vegan diet without vitamin supplementation is vitamin B12 deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

E) INCORRECT:

Although children with poorly controlled inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) can develop zinc deficiency, they are typically asymptomatic and do not present with acrodermatitis (a feature seen in infants with genetic defects in zinc absorption). Furthermore, zinc deficiency does not result in a macrocytic anemia (which this patient has), and rash is not typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl presents for a well-child visit. She has not had any major illnesses or injuries since her last visit 2 years ago. She is doing well in school and is involved in sports and dance. She reports no chest pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, or joint pain during exercise but notes that, during the past several weeks, she has felt more fatigued than usual during basketball games and practices. She is otherwise well and has no other complaints. Her menses are regular without prolonged or heavy bleeding.
She reports that she eats a healthy diet and that, about 3 years ago, she began adhering to a strict vegan diet (no meat or fish) because she "does not want to be mean to animals." She typically eats a bowl of iron-fortified cereal for breakfast. She does not take a multivitamin.
Her vital signs and physical examination are normal.
A complete blood count shows a hemoglobin concentration of 10.5 g/dL (reference range, 12–16) and a mean corpuscular volume of 100 μm3 (78–102).
Which one of the following laboratory studies is most likely to reveal the underlying cause of this patient’s fatigue?

choices.text: Iron level, total iron-binding capacity, and ferritin level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s daily consumption of iron-fortified cereal should make iron deficiency a less likely cause for anemia. In addition, her blood work reveals megaloblastic anemia; a menstruating teenager without adequate iron in their diet would be more likely to have microcytic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Zinc deficiency would be less likely to cause fatigue than vitamin B12 deficiency in a patient not regularly taking vitamin B12 supplementation.

C) CORRECT:

Strict vegan diets — which eliminate all animal products, including milk products and eggs — have become increasingly popular among adolescents. Although these diets may be healthier than a typical diet (because they contain less saturated fat and more servings of fruit and vegetables), extra care must be taken to ensure adequate intake of vitamins and nutrients, including calcium, vitamin D, vitamin B12, iron, and protein.

People may gradually develop anemia after switching to a vegan diet and may be asymptomatic or have only subtle symptoms, such as fatigue. The most common cause of anemia in people consuming a strict vegan diet without vitamin supplementation is vitamin B12 deficiency. Of note, patients with vitamin B12 deficiency may present with neurologic symptoms rather than anemia, because adequate intake of folate (present in many food items) may partially correct the anemia that would be expected with vitamin B12 deficiency.

Key learning point: Fatigue in an adolescent girl who eats a strict vegan diet is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's reported consumption of orange juice should at least partially reduce her risk of vitamin D deficiency. Symptoms of severe vitamin D deficiency include bone and muscle pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Folate intake is typically adequate in vegan diets.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 6-month history of intermittent episodes of upper abdominal pain after eating. The pain does not radiate and is occasionally associated with bloating and nausea. She also reports worsening fatigue and a pins-and-needles sensation in her hands and feet for the last 3 months. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus well controlled with an insulin pump. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. The abdomen is soft and there is no tenderness. On neurologic examination, sensation to pinprick is decreased in the feet bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.6 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
111 μm3


Leukocyte count
6800/mm3



Hemoglobin A1c
5.9%


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peptic ulcer disease (PUD), which is most commonly caused by Helicobacter pylori infection, can manifest with postprandial abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. Although gastrointestinal bleeding in PUD may also cause anemia, it is typically normocytic (due to acute blood loss) or microcytic (resulting from iron deficiency). Vitamin B12 deficiency is not a feature of PUD.

B) CORRECT:

Dyspepsia and features of vitamin B12 deficiency in a patient with an autoimmune disease (type 1 diabetes mellitus) suggest autoimmune metaplastic atrophic gastritis (AMAG). Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells in AMAG causes achlorhydria and hypergastrinemia, which can progress to hyperplasia of enterochromaffin-like cells and subsequent carcinoid tumors. Furthermore, autoantibodies against intrinsic factor lead to vitamin B12 malabsorption and pernicious anemia. AMAG is also associated with an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy with biopsy is the diagnostic test of choice for atrophic gastritis. Vitamin B12 replacement therapy is indicated for patients with vitamin B12 deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) can manifest with abdominal discomfort and vitamin B12 deficiency (due to bacterial utilization of vitamins). However, other features of SIBO, such as diarrhea, steatorrhea, flatulence, and weight loss are absent in this patient. Moreover, this patient does not have typical risk factors for SIBO, such as an anatomic cause (e.g., short bowel syndrome, inflammatory bowel disease) or a motility disorder (e.g., irritable bowel syndrome). While poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus can cause intestinal motility disorders, this patient's normal HbA1c indicates good glycemic control

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic pancreatitis can manifest with postprandial abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. Chronic pancreatitis can further lead to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, which reduces the uptake of the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 complex in the terminal ileum. However, this patient has no risk factors for chronic pancreatitis, such as heavy alcohol use, pancreatic duct obstruction, or tobacco use, making another diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Gastroparesis can manifest with postprandial abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea and is most commonly caused by autonomic neuropathy due to poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus. This patient's sensory loss (decreased sensation to pinprick) could be caused by diabetic neuropathy. However, her HbA1c is within normal limits, indicating good glycemic control. Furthermore, diabetes mellitus does not cause macrocytic anemia.
questions.hint: Macrocytic anemia in combination with symmetrical peripheral neuropathy raises suspicion for vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of type 1 diabetes presents with lower-extremity paresthesias. He has not had any prior surgeries. On examination, he has conjunctival pallor, scattered areas of hypopigmentation, and diminished vibration and cutaneous sensation of the lower extremities in a boot-like distribution. Laboratory studies show macrocytic anemia and leukopenia. Results of routine chemical tests, albumin levels, iron studies, thyroid function tests, and liver function tests are within normal ranges. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Whipple disease is a rare, systemic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei and primarily causes malabsorption. Weight loss, diarrhea, joint pain, and arthritis are common presenting symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and signs are consistent with vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency is a common cause of macrocytic anemia and, in advanced cases, pancytopenia. Neurologic sequelae from vitamin B12 deficiency include paresthesias, peripheral neuropathy, and demyelination of the corticospinal tract and dorsal columns. Vitamin B12 deficiency has also been linked to psychiatric disorders, including depression, dementia, and, in rare instances, psychosis.

Measurement of metabolites such as methylmalonic acid and homocysteine has been shown to be more diagnostic of vitamin B12 deficiency than measurement of serum B12 levels alone.

Scattered areas of hypopigmentation are most suggestive of a diagnosis of vitiligo. In a patient with type 1 diabetes and vitiligo, the most likely cause of vitamin B12 deficiency is pernicious anemia. Elevated antiparietal-cell antibodies and anti-intrinsic factor antibodies, along with chronic atrophic gastritis on endoscopy, are also found in patients with pernicious anemia.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with lower-extremity paresthesias and a macrocytic anemia is pernicious anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a genetic syndrome that typically manifests with weakness of the foot and lower-leg muscles, which may result in foot drop and a high-stepped gait with frequent tripping or falls. Foot deformities, such as high arches and hammer toes, are also characteristic.

D) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease would be unusual in the absence of abdominal pain, diarrhea, or signs of malabsorption on laboratory evaluation. Although celiac disease could manifest with an iron-deficiency anemia, this would be microcytic.

E) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis is a cause of a sensory-predominant peripheral neuropathy but is not typically associated with type 1 diabetes or macrocytosis.
questions.hint: A peripheral blood smear might show hypersegmented neutrophils.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of numbness and tingling in his fingers and toes for the past month. He also describes difficulty with balance while walking. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.5 g/dL. Serum homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels are elevated. Peripheral blood smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although sulfa drugs can trigger hemolytic anemia in patients with G6PD deficiency, this patient shows no signs of hemolysis (jaundice, scleral icterus) or G6PD deficiency (Heinz bodies, bite cells) on blood smear. Furthermore, G6PD deficiency would not explain this patient's neurological symptoms or elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels.

B) CORRECT:

Cyanocobalamin supplementation can prevent cobalamin deficiency (vitamin B12 deficiency), which results in impaired red blood cell (RBC) formation and improper myelination of the nervous system. Vitamin B12 deficiency manifests with megaloblastic anemia, symmetrical peripheral neuropathy, and subacute combined degeneration. A buildup of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (MMA) is also characteristic and helps distinguish vitamin B12 deficiency from folate deficiency, which presents with normal levels of MMA.

Key learning point: Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia, elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid, and neurologic symptoms, all of which can be prevented with cyanocobalamin supplementation.
Image Description:

Peripheral blood smear (H&E stain; very high magnification)

A large granulocyte (dashed outline) with a hypersegmented nucleus (blue overlay) is surrounded by red blood cells.

The presence of hypersegmented granulocytes in a peripheral blood smear indicates megaloblastic anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Lead-based paint exposure, resulting in lead poisoning, can present with anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and ataxia, which are all seen in this patient. However, lead poisoning would not affect methylmalonic acid or homocysteine levels, nor does this patient's history suggest lead exposure.

D) INCORRECT:

Although pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency can result in anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and elevated homocysteine levels, peripheral blood smear typically shows basophilic stippling of erythrocytes (due to sideroblastic anemia) rather than hypersegmented neutrophils. Furthermore, vitamin B6 deficiency does not explain this patient's elevated methylmalonic acid levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Although folate deficiency manifests with megaloblastic anemia (low Hb, hypersegmented neutrophils) and causes elevated homocysteine levels, which are seen in this patient, neurological manifestations would not be expected. Moreover, methylmalonic acid levels would be normal.
questions.hint: Elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels suggest a specific nutritional deficiency that can be caused by infection with the tapeworm Diphyllobothrium latum.

Three years ago, she had an ileocecal resection. On physical examination, she is thin and pale, with conjunctival and palatal pallor. Her pulse is 110/min. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory findings include the following levels:

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In addition to signs and symptoms of anemia, the most common manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are neurologic changes. Irritability, memory loss, and cerebellar ataxia (resulting from demyelination of the central nervous system) can occur but are much less common than paresthesias and ataxia.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased bruising, bleeding gums, and petechiae are typically seen in patients with vitamin C deficiency, not vitamin B12 deficiency. These symptoms are the hallmark of scurvy.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s vitamin B12 deficiency was likely caused by diminished absorption of vitamin B12 as a result of intestinal inflammation secondary to Crohn disease with ileal involvement.

In addition to signs and symptoms of anemia, the most common manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are neurologic changes. The most common and early neurologic changes are caused by myelin degeneration of the dorsal and lateral spinal columns, leading to paresthesias and ataxia as a result of a loss of vibration and position sense. This neuropathy, which affects the legs more frequently than the arms, may progress to severe weakness, spasticity, and clonus. Irritability, memory loss, and cerebellar ataxia (resulting from demyelination of the central nervous system) can also occur but are much less common than paresthesias and ataxia.

Key learning point: In addition to signs and symptoms of anemia, the major clinical manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency in an adolescent with chronic gastrointestinal disease are neurologic changes, including ataxia and paresthesias related to demyelination of the lateral and dorsal spinal cord.

D) INCORRECT:

Jaundiced skin and sclerae would be seen in patients with hemolysis as an explanation for their anemia. There is no indication from this patient’s history or laboratory results that she has an active hemolytic process.

E) INCORRECT:

An erythematous rash involving the perioral and perianal areas is most commonly associated with zinc deficiency, not vitamin B12 deficiency. Although children with poorly controlled inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) can develop zinc deficiency, they are typically asymptomatic and do not present with acrodermatitis (a feature seen in infants with genetic defects in zinc absorption). Furthermore, zinc deficiency does not result in a macrocytic anemia (which this patient has), and rash is not typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient has a low hemoglobin level and elevated mean corpuscular volume, consistent with a macrocytic anemia. These laboratory results, together with the patient’s uncontrolled gastrointestinal disease, raise concern for vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents with new numbness and tingling in both feet. Her history includes type 2 diabetes well controlled on metformin and gastroesophageal reflux disease treated with omeprazole. She does not have a previous history of neuropathy. Vital signs are within normal limits. She has diminished vibratory and position sense in both feet and mild hyperreflexia on testing of ankle reflexes. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


Leukocyte count
4500/mm3



Mean corpuscular volume
110 μm3


Hemoglobin
10 g/dL


Platelet count
250,000/mm3



Reticulocyte count
1%


Which one of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of macrocytosis, anemia, and neurologic findings suggests vitamin B12 deficiency. Long-term use of metformin and long-term use of proton pump inhibitors have been associated with development of low vitamin B12 levels; the presumed mechanism is interference with B12 absorption. Although the incidence of symptomatic B12 deficiency among long-term users of these medications remains unclear, a vitamin B12 level should be checked in this patient.

The neurologic manifestations of B12 deficiency include involvement of the dorsal spinal columns (with impairment of position sense and vibratory sense) and the lateral spinal columns. Early in the clinical course, involvement of upper motor neurons in the lateral spinal columns may cause hyperreflexia.

Key learning point: Long-term use of metformin or a proton pump inhibitor has been associated with development of low levels of vitamin B12 .

B) INCORRECT:

Diabetic neuropathy could explain new-onset distal sensory symptoms, but this peripheral neuropathy usually presents with hyporeflexia (not hyperreflexia). Additionally, diabetes does not typically cause macrocytic anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

In otherwise healthy people, inadequate dietary intake alone almost never causes vitamin B12 deficiency, except in strict vegetarians.

D) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic neuropathy could explain new-onset distal sensory symptoms, but this peripheral neuropathy usually presents with hyporeflexia (not hyperreflexia). Additionally, paraneoplastic effects of malignancy typically do not cause macrocytic anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia is invariably associated with reticulocytosis (unless a patient has an additional condition that suppresses hematopoiesis). This patient has no reticulocytosis, and none of her medications typically cause drug-induced hemolysis.
questions.hint: A peripheral blood smear might show hypersegmented neutrophils.

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravid woman at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for her initial prenatal visit. She has had generalized fatigue, shortness of breath, and a tingling sensation in her toes over the past 2 months. She has followed a strict vegan diet since the age of 13 years. Examination shows pale conjunctivae and a shiny tongue. Sensation to vibration and position is decreased over the upper and lower extremities. When asked to stand, hold her arms in front of her, and close her eyes, she loses her balance and takes a step backward. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While hypocalcemia may cause paresthesias of the distal extremities, it cannot explain this patient's pallor, generalized fatigue, shortness of breath, or glossitis. Also, the neurological findings of sensory loss and positive Romberg test are not consistent with hypocalcemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Folic acid deficiency may occur during pregnancy and can manifest with pallor, generalized fatigue, shortness of breath, glossitis, and macrocytic anemia. However, folic acid deficiency does not result in neurological manifestations (e.g., paresthesia). All pregnant women should receive daily folic acid supplementation in order to prevent neural tube defects in the child.

C) CORRECT:

Conjunctival pallor, fatigue, shortness of breath, and glossitis indicate a nutrient deficiency anemia. Given the concomitant features of subacute combined degeneration (paresthesias, loss of vibratory sensation and proprioception, positive Romberg test), this patient most likely has a vitamin B12 deficiency. A strict vegan diet typically does not have a sufficient amount of vitamin B12and requires supplementation. In addition, the demand for vitamin B12 is higher during pregnancy and lactation.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism may manifest with increased fatigue and macrocytic anemia, however, the absence of other features associated with hypothyroidism (e.g., bradycardia, cold intolerance, dry skin, hyporeflexia, inappropriate maternal or fetal weight gain) suggests a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Pregnant women are at increased risk of iron deficiency anemia (IDA), the most common form of anemia in pregnancy, as a result of plasma expansion and increased production of erythrocytes and should therefore receive low-dose iron supplementation (30 mg/day) starting at the first prenatal visit. IDA may manifest with pallor, generalized fatigue, shortness of breath, and glossitis. However, patients with IDA typically do not display any neurological symptoms; an IDA would not account for this patient's paresthesias, loss of vibratory sensation and proprioception, or the positive Romberg test.
questions.hint: A peripheral blood smear might show hypersegmented neutrophils.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the office because of generalized fatigue and numbness of his legs and toes for the past 5 months. He underwent a partial gastrectomy 15 years ago. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and glossitis. Sensation to vibration and position is absent over the lower extremities. He has a broad-based gait. The patient sways when he stands with his feet together and closes his eyes. Laboratory studies show anemia and thrombocytopenia. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low serum iron levels are seen in iron deficiency anemia (IDA). Although this patient is anemic, IDA does not explain his neurologic findings. Moreover, reactive thrombocytosis, not thrombocytopenia, would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid are seen in multiple sclerosis (MS), which typically manifests in women 20–50 years old. Patients with MS often experience visual impairment and spastic motor weakness due to demyelination of the spinal cord tracts. The dorsal column of the spinal cord can be involved, causing loss of vibration and proprioception. However, the lack of other characteristic symptoms of MS and absent demographic risk factors make the diagnosis unlikely. Also, MS does not cause anemia.

C) CORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency results in elevated methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels. Vitamin B12 is a coenzyme for methylmalonyl-CoA mutase in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. Thus, if there are insufficient levels of vitamin B12, methylmalonyl-CoA cannot be broken down, leading to an accumulation of MMA and its precursor, propionyl-CoA. These products, along with their associated odd-chain fatty acids, cannot be completely metabolized, which causes neuron damage (due to propionyl-CoA replacing acetyl-CoA in neuronal membranes), demyelination, and consequent neurological manifestations. This patient's vitamin B12 deficiency is likely the result of malabsorption due to partial gastrectomy and the loss of parietal cells that produce intrinsic factor, which is necessary for vitamin B12 absorption in the terminal ileum.

Vitamin B12 deficiency also results in elevated homocysteine levels because vitamin B12 functions as a coenzyme in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine via methionine synthase. Hyperhomocysteinemia is also seen in folate deficiency, which manifests with megaloblastic anemia. Unlike vitamin B12 deficiency, MMA is normal in folate deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Basophilic stippling of RBCs is a nonspecific finding of lead intoxication and manifests with anemia. However, this patient lacks other signs of lead poisoning (e.g., abdominal pain, arthralgias, myalgias, a decline in neurocognitive function, and nephropathy). In addition, lead poisoning would not explain this patient's dorsal column dysfunction.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Pappenheim stain)

The erythrocytes contain purple spots (green overlay), which are consistent with cytoplasmic granules. The large, heavily spotted cell in the center of the right image appears to be a neutrophil. In the center of the left image, there is a normoblast with a prominent nucleus, which is not usually present in peripheral blood and suggests impaired erythropoiesis.

Basophilic stippling describes the appearance of red blood granules, which are mainly composed of aggregating ribosomes. It is characteristic of impaired red blood cell maturation.

E) INCORRECT:

Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test is a common screening test for syphilis. Patients with tertiary syphilis and consequent tabes dorsalis may also present with ataxic gait, sensory abnormalities, and a positive Romberg test. However, this patient lacks the other symptoms of tertiary syphilis (e.g., gummas, meningism) and does not have any clear risk factors (e.g., high-risk sexual behavior). Also, syphilis does not cause anemia.
questions.hint: Anemia, thrombocytopenia, glossitis, signs of dorsal column dysfunction (absent vibration and position sense, positive Romberg test), and a broad-based gait are suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, epigastric discomfort, abdominal bloating, and tingling in his hands that has progressed during the past 6 months. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide, methyldopa, and famotidine. On examination, he appears pale, and his tongue is smooth and swollen. Sensation of light touch is reduced in his hands and feet. His Romberg test is abnormal. Results of laboratory studies are shown:


Hemoglobin
7.5 g/dL


Hematocrit
20%


Leukocyte count
3300/mm3


Platelet count
88,000/mm3


Mean corpuscular volume
103/μm3


Reticulocyte count
0.8%


Serum



 Bilirubin
2.4 mg/dL


 Direct bilirubin
0.4 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia is not associated with neurologic disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Myelodysplastic syndrome can be a cause for pancytopenia but is not typically associated with paresthesias or loss of balance.

C) INCORRECT:

Babesiosis can range from subclinical to fulminant illness, characterized by severe hemolytic anemia and multisystem failure. The peripheral smear may show evidence of hemolysis (basophilic stippling, hemolysis of red cells, nucleated red cells, and schistocytes), but it is not a cause of macrocytosis.

D) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis of macrocytosis with pancytopenia includes infections (e.g., tickborne disease and HIV), vitamin deficiencies (vitamin B12 or folate), certain medications, and autoimmune, neoplastic, and paraneoplastic causes. Glossitis is more often associated with vitamin B12 deficiency than with other conditions in the differential diagnosis. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with a macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils, consistent with megaloblastic anemia. There is increased hemolysis related to premature destruction of red cells, which is associated with laboratory findings such as an increased bilirubin level. Once vitamin B12 deficiency is confirmed, further workup should be aimed at establishing the etiologic factors. The causes of vitamin B12 deficiency include pernicious anemia, Helicobacter pylori infection, chronic gastritis, and long-term use of acid-suppressive therapy.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a sore tongue, macrocytosis, pancytopenia, and paresthesias is vitamin B12 deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism typically causes macrocytosis and mild anemia.
questions.hint: This patient’s symptoms are attributable to severe anemia.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man returns to the clinic 9 months after a partial small bowel resection that included the terminal ileum. He reports progressive fatigue, numbness in his feet, and difficulty with balance over the past 3 months. He appears pale. Neurological examination reveals decreased position sense in the lower extremities (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Hemoglobin
100 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


Peripheral blood smear: Enlarged red blood cells
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency anemia typically presents with microcytic anemia, not macrocytic anemia as indicated by the enlarged red blood cells. Additionally, neurological symptoms such as numbness and balance difficulties are not characteristic of iron deficiency anemia, but are associated with vitamin B12 deficiency, especially after terminal ileum resection.

B) CORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency manifests with macrocytic anemia and neurological abnormalities due to its role in DNA synthesis and myelin formation. The terminal ileum is the primary site for absorption of the vitamin B12–intrinsic factor complex, making patients with ileal resection susceptible to deficiency. Symptoms such as fatigue and pallor correlate with anemia, while decreased position sense and balance difficulties reflect spinal cord dorsal column demyelination. The symptom onset timeline aligns with gradual vitamin B12 store depletion following reduced absorption.

Key learning point: Vitamin B12 deficiency can occur after terminal ileum resection and can lead to anemia and neurological symptoms such as loss of position sense and difficulty walking.

C) INCORRECT:

Copper deficiency can cause neurological symptoms and anemia, but it is absorbed in the stomach and proximal duodenum, not the terminal ileum. The macrocytic anemia and surgical history involving the terminal ileum suggest a deficiency in a nutrient absorbed there, such as vitamin B12, rather than copper.

D) INCORRECT:

Folate deficiency can cause macrocytic anemia and fatigue but is not typically associated with neurological symptoms like numbness or balance issues. Folate is absorbed in the jejunum, not the terminal ileum, making it an unlikely cause given the patient's surgical history and neurological symptoms.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents with six months of progressive numbness and tingling in his feet and increasing difficulty walking. He occasionally feels off-balance, especially in dimly lit areas. He follows a strict vegan diet with minimal supplementation and reports fatigue and palpitations. He denies alcohol use. Examination reveals diminished proprioception in the lower extremities, significantly reduced vibration sense, absent ankle reflexes, and bilateral extensor plantar responses (see lab results and image).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
95 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


MCV
110 fL
80 - 95 fL


Lactate dehydrogenase
180 IU/L
60 - 160 IU/L



Which deficiency best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms, including diminished proprioception, reduced vibration sense, and abnormal plantar responses, suggest subacute combined degeneration due to vitamin B12 deficiency. This condition involves demyelination of the dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts. Vitamin B12 is essential for methionine synthase and methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, and its deficiency disrupts DNA synthesis, leading to macrocytic anemia with elevated mean corpuscular volume and low hemoglobin. The increased lactate dehydrogenase indicates ineffective erythropoiesis. A strict vegan diet predisposes individuals to vitamin B12 deficiency, as it is primarily found in animal products.

Key learning point: Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, leading to neurological symptoms such as unsteady gait, decreased proprioception, positive Babinski sign, and absent reflexes, along with macrocytic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Folate deficiency causes macrocytic anemia but does not lead to the neurological deficits seen in vitamin B12 deficiency, such as diminished proprioception and abnormal plantar responses. The patient's folate level is normal, making folate deficiency unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Copper deficiency can cause neurologic symptoms like sensory ataxia and dorsal column dysfunction, but it usually presents with normocytic or microcytic anemia, not macrocytic anemia. It is more common after bariatric surgery or excessive zinc intake, not a vegan diet.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin E deficiency can cause neurological symptoms like ataxia and peripheral neuropathy, but it is typically associated with malabsorption syndromes, not a vegan diet. It does not cause macrocytic anemia, which is present in this patient.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man presents with increased fatigue and numbness in his fingertips. He has a history of Crohn disease and underwent surgical resection of his terminal ileum eight months ago due to a stricture. Prior endoscopy confirmed intact intrinsic factor production (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
110 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


MCV
103 fL
80 - 95 fL


Methylmalonic acid
Elevated
Normal: < 0.4 μmol/L



Which of the following interventions is most likely to prevent further progression of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While parenteral vitamin B12 is necessary for patients with impaired absorption, the intravenous route is not standard. Intramuscular injections are preferred due to their reliable pharmacokinetics and ease of administration. Intravenous administration may lead to rapid clearance and requires more monitoring.

B) INCORRECT:

Folate supplementation addresses folate deficiency but does not correct vitamin B12 deficiency, indicated by elevated methylmalonic acid. While folate may improve macrocytic anemia, it does not prevent neurological complications of vitamin B12 deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Daily low-dose oral vitamin B12 is ineffective in this patient due to the absence of the terminal ileum, which is essential for receptor-mediated absorption. Only a small fraction of an oral dose is absorbed passively, insufficient to correct the deficiency caused by the resection.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with terminal ileum resection, vitamin B12 absorption is impaired due to the loss of the primary absorption site. Despite intact intrinsic factor production, the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex cannot be absorbed, leading to deficiency. The patient's macrocytic anemia and elevated methylmalonic acid levels confirm vitamin B12 deficiency. Monthly intramuscular vitamin B12 bypasses the gastrointestinal tract, ensuring adequate replenishment and preventing further hematologic and neurologic complications.

Key learning point: After resection of the terminal ileum, vitamin B12 absorption is impaired, necessitating parenteral replacement to prevent deficiency.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, numbness in his hands and feet, and an unsteady gait for the past few months. He underwent a total gastrectomy 7 years ago. He takes a daily multivitamin, but no other supplements. Examination reveals decreased vibration sense in the lower extremities. Blood tests show macrocytosis with a hemoglobin of 9.5 g/dL and a normal RBC folate level.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency anemia presents as microcytic anemia, not macrocytic anemia with neurological symptoms. The patient's macrocytosis and neurological deficits suggest vitamin B12 deficiency. Iron infusion is for confirmed iron deficiency, which is not indicated by the current findings.

B) CORRECT:

Total gastrectomy eliminates intrinsic factor production, crucial for vitamin B12 absorption in the terminal ileum. This patient presents with fatigue, macrocytic anemia, and neurological symptoms, indicating vitamin B12 deficiency. Oral supplementation is ineffective due to impaired absorption. Intramuscular administration bypasses the need for intrinsic factor, ensuring reliable absorption and rapid correction, especially important for neurological symptoms.

Key learning point: Megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms in a patient with a history of total gastrectomy are indicative of vitamin B12 deficiency due to lack of intrinsic factor necessary for B12 absorption.

C) INCORRECT:

Intranasal vitamin B12 can be used for mild deficiencies but is less predictable in severe cases with neurological symptoms. The patient's total gastrectomy impairs gastrointestinal absorption, and intranasal therapy may not achieve the high serum levels needed for rapid correction.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral folate supplementation addresses folate deficiency, which presents with macrocytic anemia but not neurological symptoms. The patient's normal RBC folate level and neurological findings suggest vitamin B12 deficiency, not folate deficiency. Total gastrectomy affects vitamin B12 absorption due to intrinsic factor loss.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, difficulty walking, and decreased sensation in his feet. He reports intermittent numbness in his hands. He has no significant dietary restrictions. Examination shows pale conjunctiva and decreased vibration sense in both lower extremities. Neurological examination reveals diminished proprioception and an ataxic gait. Additional labs, including thyroid function tests and serum electrolytes, are within normal limits (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
90 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


MCV
118 fL
80 - 95 fL


Folic acid
10 μg/L
3 - 17 μg/L


Vitamin B12

110 ng/L
160 - 900 ng/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Transfusion of packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral cobalamin can be effective in mild vitamin B12 deficiency without malabsorption or neurological symptoms. However, this patient has significant macrocytic anemia and neurological deficits, suggesting malabsorption, possibly due to pernicious anemia. Oral supplementation relies on passive diffusion, which is insufficient for rapid correction in such cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the patient is anemic, his hemoglobin level is not critically low, and there is no hemodynamic instability. The anemia is due to vitamin B12 deficiency, which requires correction of the deficiency rather than transfusion. Transfusion does not address the underlying cause or neurological symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

The patient's normal folate level and neurological symptoms suggest vitamin B12 deficiency, not folate deficiency. While folate supplementation can improve hematologic parameters, it does not address neurological deficits and may mask vitamin B12 deficiency, allowing neurological deterioration to continue.

D) CORRECT:

The patient presents with macrocytic anemia and neurological symptoms, including impaired vibration sense and ataxia, indicative of vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 is crucial for myelin synthesis and red blood cell production. Deficiency leads to neuronal dysfunction and megaloblastic anemia. Intramuscular administration is preferred in cases with neurological involvement, as it bypasses gastrointestinal absorption issues, ensuring rapid and effective delivery. This approach is essential to prevent further neurodegenerative changes and improve hematologic status.

Key learning point: Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause macrocytic anemia and neurological symptoms, and parenteral B12 supplementation is the preferred treatment, especially when neurological symptoms are present.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of intermittent episodes of upper abdominal pain after eating. The pain does not radiate and is sometimes associated with bloating and nausea. She also reports worsening fatigue and a pins-and-needles sensation in her hands and feet for the past 3 months. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus, well controlled with an insulin pump. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. On examination, she has conjunctival pallor. Her abdomen is soft and non-tender. Neurologic examination reveals decreased sensation to pinprick in both feet. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
96 g/L (115–155)


Mean corpuscular volume (MCV), blood

111 fL (80–100)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
6.8 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), blood
5.9% (4.8%–6.0%)


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastroparesis can manifest with postprandial abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea and is most commonly caused by autonomic neuropathy due to poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus. This patient's sensory loss (decreased sensation to pinprick) could be caused by diabetic neuropathy. However, her HbA1c is within normal limits, indicating good glycemic control. Furthermore, diabetes mellitus does not cause macrocytic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Peptic ulcer disease (PUD), which is most commonly caused by Helicobacter pylori infection, can manifest with postprandial abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. Although gastrointestinal bleeding in PUD may also cause anemia, it is typically normocytic (due to acute blood loss) or microcytic (resulting from iron deficiency). Vitamin B12 deficiency is not a feature of PUD.

C) INCORRECT:

Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) can manifest with abdominal discomfort and vitamin B12 deficiency (due to bacterial utilization of vitamins). However, other features of SIBO, such as diarrhea, steatorrhea, flatulence, and weight loss are absent in this patient. Moreover, this patient does not have typical risk factors for SIBO, such as an anatomic cause (e.g., short bowel syndrome, inflammatory bowel disease) or a motility disorder (e.g., irritable bowel syndrome). While poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus can cause intestinal motility disorders, this patient's normal HbA1c indicates good glycemic control

D) CORRECT:

Dyspepsia and features of vitamin B12 deficiency in a patient with an autoimmune disease (type 1 diabetes mellitus) suggest autoimmune metaplastic atrophic gastritis (AMAG). Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells in AMAG causes achlorhydria and hypergastrinemia, which can progress to hyperplasia of enterochromaffin-like cells and subsequent carcinoid tumors. Furthermore, autoantibodies against intrinsic factor lead to vitamin B12 malabsorption and pernicious anemia. AMAG is also associated with an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy with biopsy is the diagnostic test of choice for atrophic gastritis. Vitamin B12 replacement therapy is indicated for patients with vitamin B12 deficiency.

Key learning point: Autoimmune metaplastic atrophic gastritis causes parietal cell loss, leading to achlorhydria, intrinsic factor deficiency, vitamin B12 malabsorption, and increased risk of pernicious anemia and gastric cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic pancreatitis can manifest with postprandial abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. Chronic pancreatitis can further lead to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, which reduces the uptake of the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 complex in the terminal ileum. However, this patient has no risk factors for chronic pancreatitis, such as heavy alcohol use, pancreatic duct obstruction, or tobacco use, making another diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: Macrocytic anemia in combination with symmetrical peripheral neuropathy raises suspicion for vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: You are seeing a 35-year-old man with a history of type 1 diabetes who presents with lower-extremity paresthesias. He has no history of prior surgeries. On examination, he has conjunctival pallor, scattered areas of hypopigmentation, and decreased vibration and cutaneous sensation in the lower extremities in a boot-like distribution. Laboratory studies reveal macrocytic anemia and leukopenia. Routine chemical tests, albumin, iron studies, thyroid function tests, and liver function tests are all within normal limits. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Whipple disease is a rare, systemic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei and primarily causes malabsorption. Weight loss, diarrhea, joint pain, and arthritis are common presenting symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis is a cause of a sensory-predominant peripheral neuropathy but is not typically associated with type 1 diabetes or macrocytosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease would be unusual in the absence of abdominal pain, diarrhea, or signs of malabsorption on laboratory evaluation. Although celiac disease could manifest with an iron-deficiency anemia, this would be microcytic.

D) INCORRECT:

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a genetic syndrome that typically manifests with weakness of the foot and lower-leg muscles, which may result in foot drop and a high-stepped gait with frequent tripping or falls. Foot deformities, such as high arches and hammer toes, are also characteristic.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and signs are consistent with vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency is a common cause of macrocytic anemia and, in advanced cases, pancytopenia. Neurologic sequelae from vitamin B12 deficiency include paresthesias, peripheral neuropathy, and demyelination of the corticospinal tract and dorsal columns. Vitamin B12 deficiency has also been linked to psychiatric disorders, including depression, dementia, and, in rare instances, psychosis.

Measurement of metabolites such as methylmalonic acid and homocysteine has been shown to be more diagnostic of vitamin B12 deficiency than measurement of serum B12 levels alone.

Scattered areas of hypopigmentation are most suggestive of a diagnosis of vitiligo. In a patient with type 1 diabetes and vitiligo, the most likely cause of vitamin B12 deficiency is pernicious anemia. Elevated antiparietal-cell antibodies and anti-intrinsic factor antibodies, along with chronic atrophic gastritis on endoscopy, are also found in patients with pernicious anemia.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with lower-extremity paresthesias and a macrocytic anemia is pernicious anemia.
questions.hint: A peripheral blood smear might show hypersegmented neutrophils.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of numbness and tingling in his fingers and toes. He also reports difficulty maintaining balance while walking. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 95 g/L (125–170). Serum homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels are elevated. Peripheral blood smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils. Which one of the following is most likely to have prevented his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lead-based paint exposure, resulting in lead poisoning, can present with anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and ataxia, which are all seen in this patient. However, lead poisoning would not affect methylmalonic acid or homocysteine levels, nor does this patient's history suggest lead exposure.

B) INCORRECT:

Although folate deficiency manifests with megaloblastic anemia (low Hb, hypersegmented neutrophils) and causes elevated homocysteine levels, which are seen in this patient, neurological manifestations would not be expected. Moreover, methylmalonic acid levels would be normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Although pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency can result in anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and elevated homocysteine levels, peripheral blood smear typically shows basophilic stippling of erythrocytes (due to sideroblastic anemia) rather than hypersegmented neutrophils. Furthermore, vitamin B6 deficiency does not explain this patient's elevated methylmalonic acid levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Although sulfa drugs can trigger hemolytic anemia in patients with G6PD deficiency, this patient shows no signs of hemolysis (jaundice, scleral icterus) or G6PD deficiency (Heinz bodies, bite cells) on blood smear. Furthermore, G6PD deficiency would not explain this patient's neurological symptoms or elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels.

E) CORRECT:

Cyanocobalamin supplementation can prevent cobalamin deficiency (vitamin B12 deficiency), which results in impaired red blood cell (RBC) formation and improper myelination of the nervous system. Vitamin B12 deficiency manifests with megaloblastic anemia, symmetrical peripheral neuropathy, and subacute combined degeneration. A buildup of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (MMA) is also characteristic and helps distinguish vitamin B12 deficiency from folate deficiency, which presents with normal levels of MMA.

Key learning point: Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia and neurologic symptoms, and is prevented by cyanocobalamin supplementation.
Image Description:

Peripheral blood smear (H&E stain; very high magnification)

A large granulocyte (dashed outline) with a hypersegmented nucleus (blue overlay) is surrounded by red blood cells.

The presence of hypersegmented granulocytes in a peripheral blood smear indicates megaloblastic anemia.
questions.hint: Elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels suggest a specific nutritional deficiency that can be caused by infection with the tapeworm Diphyllobothrium latum.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 15-year-old girl in your clinic for follow-up of her ileal Crohn disease, diagnosed 5 years ago, which has been poorly controlled due to difficulty with treatment adherence. She underwent an ileocecal resection 3 years ago. On examination, she appears thin and pale, with conjunctival and palatal pallor. Her pulse is 110/min. The remainder of the examination is normal. Laboratory findings are as follows:


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
6.6 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood

71 g/L (115–155)


Hematocrit (Hct), blood
0.209 L/L (0.38–0.50)


Mean corpuscular volume (MCV), blood

110 fL (80–100)


Platelet count, blood
340 × 109/L (130–380)


Which one of the following clinical features is most likely to be associated with this patient’s anemia?

choices.text: Erythematous rash surrounding the mouth and anus.
Memory loss and irritability related to demyelination of the frontal cortex.
Increased bruising, gum bleeding, and development of petechiae.
Ataxia and paresthesias related to demyelination of the lateral and dorsal spinal cord.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An erythematous rash involving the perioral and perianal areas is most commonly associated with zinc deficiency, not vitamin B12 deficiency. Although children with poorly controlled inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) can develop zinc deficiency, they are typically asymptomatic and do not present with acrodermatitis (a feature seen in infants with genetic defects in zinc absorption). Furthermore, zinc deficiency does not result in a macrocytic anemia (which this patient has), and rash is not typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Jaundiced skin and sclerae would be seen in patients with hemolysis as an explanation for their anemia. There is no indication from this patient’s history or laboratory results that she has an active hemolytic process.

C) INCORRECT:

In addition to signs and symptoms of anemia, the most common manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are neurologic changes. Irritability, memory loss, and cerebellar ataxia (resulting from demyelination of the central nervous system) can occur but are much less common than paresthesias and ataxia.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased bruising, bleeding gums, and petechiae are typically seen in patients with vitamin C deficiency, not vitamin B12 deficiency. These symptoms are the hallmark of scurvy.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s vitamin B12 deficiency was likely caused by diminished absorption of vitamin B12 as a result of intestinal inflammation secondary to Crohn disease with ileal involvement.

In addition to signs and symptoms of anemia, the most common manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are neurologic changes. The most common and early neurologic changes are caused by myelin degeneration of the dorsal and lateral spinal columns, leading to paresthesias and ataxia as a result of a loss of vibration and position sense. This neuropathy, which affects the legs more frequently than the arms, may progress to severe weakness, spasticity, and clonus. Irritability, memory loss, and cerebellar ataxia (resulting from demyelination of the central nervous system) can also occur but are much less common than paresthesias and ataxia.

Key learning point: In addition to signs and symptoms of anemia, the major clinical manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency in an adolescent with chronic gastrointestinal disease are neurologic changes, including ataxia and paresthesias related to demyelination of the lateral and dorsal spinal cord.
questions.hint: This patient has a low hemoglobin level and elevated mean corpuscular volume, consistent with a macrocytic anemia. These laboratory results, together with the patient’s uncontrolled gastrointestinal disease, raise concern for vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman comes to your clinic with new numbness and tingling in both feet. Her medical history includes type 2 diabetes, well controlled on metformin, and gastroesophageal reflux disease treated with omeprazole. She has no previous history of neuropathy. Vital signs are normal. On examination, she has diminished vibratory and position sense in both feet and mild hyperreflexia at the ankles. Laboratory findings are as follows:


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
4.5 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Mean corpuscular volume (MCV), blood

110 fL (80–100)


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood

100 g/L (115–155)


Platelet count, blood
250 × 109/L (130–380)


Reticulocyte percentage, blood
1% (0.5–1.5)


Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic neuropathy could explain new-onset distal sensory symptoms, but this peripheral neuropathy usually presents with hyporeflexia (not hyperreflexia). Additionally, paraneoplastic effects of malignancy typically do not cause macrocytic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia is invariably associated with reticulocytosis (unless a patient has an additional condition that suppresses hematopoiesis). This patient has no reticulocytosis, and none of her medications typically cause drug-induced hemolysis.

C) CORRECT:

The combination of macrocytosis, anemia, and neurologic findings suggests vitamin B12 deficiency. Long-term use of metformin and long-term use of proton pump inhibitors have been associated with development of low vitamin B12 levels; the presumed mechanism is interference with B12 absorption. Although the incidence of symptomatic B12 deficiency among long-term users of these medications remains unclear, a vitamin B12 level should be checked in this patient.

The neurologic manifestations of B12 deficiency include involvement of the dorsal spinal columns (with impairment of position sense and vibratory sense) and the lateral spinal columns. Early in the clinical course, involvement of upper motor neurons in the lateral spinal columns may cause hyperreflexia.

Key learning point: Long-term use of metformin or a proton pump inhibitor has been associated with development of low levels of vitamin B12 .

D) INCORRECT:

Diabetic neuropathy could explain new-onset distal sensory symptoms, but this peripheral neuropathy usually presents with hyporeflexia (not hyperreflexia). Additionally, diabetes does not typically cause macrocytic anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

In otherwise healthy people, inadequate dietary intake alone almost never causes vitamin B12 deficiency, except in strict vegetarians.
questions.hint: A peripheral blood smear might show hypersegmented neutrophils.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 5-month history of generalized fatigue and numbness in his legs and toes. He has a history of partial gastrectomy 15 years ago. On examination, he has conjunctival pallor and glossitis. Sensation to vibration and position is absent in the lower extremities. His gait is broad-based, and he sways when standing with his feet together and eyes closed. Laboratory studies reveal anemia and thrombocytopenia. Which one of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low serum iron levels are seen in iron deficiency anemia (IDA). Although this patient is anemic, IDA does not explain his neurologic findings. Moreover, reactive thrombocytosis, not thrombocytopenia, would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Basophilic stippling of RBCs is a nonspecific finding of lead intoxication and manifests with anemia. However, this patient lacks other signs of lead poisoning (e.g., abdominal pain, arthralgias, myalgias, a decline in neurocognitive function, and nephropathy). In addition, lead poisoning would not explain this patient's dorsal column dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test is a common screening test for syphilis. Patients with tertiary syphilis and consequent tabes dorsalis may also present with ataxic gait, sensory abnormalities, and a positive Romberg test. However, this patient lacks the other symptoms of tertiary syphilis (e.g., gummas, meningism) and does not have any clear risk factors (e.g., high-risk sexual behavior). Also, syphilis does not cause anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid are seen in multiple sclerosis (MS), which typically manifests in women 20–50 years old. Patients with MS often experience visual impairment and spastic motor weakness due to demyelination of the spinal cord tracts. The dorsal column of the spinal cord can be involved, causing loss of vibration and proprioception. However, the lack of other characteristic symptoms of MS and absent demographic risk factors make the diagnosis unlikely. Also, MS does not cause anemia.

E) CORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency results in elevated methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels. Vitamin B12 is a coenzyme for methylmalonyl-CoA mutase in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. Thus, if there are insufficient levels of vitamin B12, methylmalonyl-CoA cannot be broken down, leading to an accumulation of MMA and its precursor, propionyl-CoA. These products, along with their associated odd-chain fatty acids, cannot be completely metabolized, which causes neuron damage (due to propionyl-CoA replacing acetyl-CoA in neuronal membranes), demyelination, and consequent neurological manifestations. This patient's vitamin B12 deficiency is likely the result of malabsorption due to partial gastrectomy and the loss of parietal cells that produce intrinsic factor, which is necessary for vitamin B12 absorption in the terminal ileum.

Vitamin B12 deficiency also results in elevated homocysteine levels because vitamin B12 functions as a coenzyme in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine via methionine synthase. Hyperhomocysteinemia is also seen in folate deficiency, which manifests with megaloblastic anemia. Unlike vitamin B12 deficiency, MMA is normal in folate deficiency.

Key learning point: Vitamin B12 deficiency causes elevated methylmalonic acid and homocysteine levels, leading to megaloblastic anemia and neurologic deficits such as dorsal column dysfunction.
questions.hint: Anemia, thrombocytopenia, glossitis, signs of dorsal column dysfunction (absent vibration and position sense, positive Romberg test), and a broad-based gait are suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, epigastric discomfort, abdominal bloating, and progressive tingling in his hands. His medications are hydrochlorothiazide, methyldopa, and famotidine. On examination, he is pale, and his tongue is smooth and swollen. Sensation to light touch is reduced in his hands and feet. His Romberg test is abnormal. Laboratory studies show the following:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood

75 g/L (125–170)


Hematocrit (Hct), blood
0.20 L/L (0.38–0.50)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
3.3 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood
88 × 109/L (130–380)


Mean corpuscular volume (MCV), blood

103 fL (80–100)


Reticulocyte percentage, blood
0.8% (0.5–1.5)


Bilirubin, total, blood
41 μmol/L (3–17)


Bilirubin, direct (conjugated), blood
6.8 μmol/L (2–9)


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism typically causes macrocytosis and mild anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Babesiosis can range from subclinical to fulminant illness, characterized by severe hemolytic anemia and multisystem failure. The peripheral smear may show evidence of hemolysis (basophilic stippling, hemolysis of red cells, nucleated red cells, and schistocytes), but it is not a cause of macrocytosis.

C) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis of macrocytosis with pancytopenia includes infections (e.g., tickborne disease and HIV), vitamin deficiencies (vitamin B12 or folate), certain medications, and autoimmune, neoplastic, and paraneoplastic causes. Glossitis is more often associated with vitamin B12 deficiency than with other conditions in the differential diagnosis. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with a macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils, consistent with megaloblastic anemia. There is increased hemolysis related to premature destruction of red cells, which is associated with laboratory findings such as an increased bilirubin level. Once vitamin B12 deficiency is confirmed, further workup should be aimed at establishing the etiologic factors. The causes of vitamin B12 deficiency include pernicious anemia, Helicobacter pylori infection, chronic gastritis, and long-term use of acid-suppressive therapy.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a sore tongue, macrocytosis, pancytopenia, and paresthesias is vitamin B12 deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia is not associated with neurologic disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Myelodysplastic syndrome can be a cause for pancytopenia but is not typically associated with paresthesias or loss of balance.
questions.hint: This patient’s symptoms are attributable to severe anemia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a 15-year history of Crohn disease, for which he underwent post-terminal ileum resection 8 years ago, presents with a 6-month history of progressive paresthesias in his hands and feet and worsening gait instability. He reports feeling particularly unsteady when showering with his eyes closed. Neurologic examination shows a positive Romberg sign. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Presence of an intention tremor on finger-to-nose testing
Hyporeflexia of the patellar and Achilles tendons
Loss of vibratory sensation in the lower extremities
Weakness of foot dorsiflexion and eversion
Decreased pain and temperature sensation in a stocking-glove distribution

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An intention tremor is a sign of dysmetria, which indicates cerebellar dysfunction. This patient's gait instability is described as sensory ataxia (loss of position sense), confirmed by the positive Romberg test, rather than cerebellar ataxia. Vitamin B12 deficiency does not typically cause cerebellar symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyporeflexia suggests a peripheral neuropathy or lower motor neuron lesion. While vitamin B12 deficiency can cause a peripheral neuropathy, the classic myelopathy (subacute combined degeneration) involves the corticospinal tracts, which would produce upper motor neuron signs like hyperreflexia and spasticity. This patient's symptoms are consistent with a pathology of the dorsal column.

C) CORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which specifically affects the dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts. The dorsal columns are responsible for transmitting vibratory and proprioceptive signals. The patient's gait instability, worsened with eye closure, and positive Romberg sign are classic manifestations of sensory ataxia from proprioceptive loss. Loss of vibratory sensation is another hallmark finding of dorsal column dysfunction and is often one of the earliest signs to appear.

D) INCORRECT:

Weakness of foot dorsiflexion and eversion is a focal weakness, suggestive of a common fibular (peroneal) nerve palsy or an L5 radiculopathy. While subacute combined degeneration can cause weakness due to involvement of the corticospinal tract, it typically manifests as an upper motor neuron pattern (spastic paresis) and is more diffuse and symmetrical, rather than focal.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased pain and temperature sensation in a stocking-glove distribution indicates damage to small nerve fibers, which transmit pain and temperature via the spinothalamic tracts. The patient's symptoms of sensory ataxia and positive Romberg sign point to dysfunction of the dorsal columns (large fibers), which mediate proprioception and vibration, not the spinothalamic tracts.
questions.hint: This patient's history of terminal ileum resection predisposes him to vitamin B12 deficiency, as the terminal ileum is the primary site of B12 absorption.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with a six-month history of progressive numbness and tingling in his feet, along with increasing difficulty with balance. He also reports feeling unusually fatigued and has noticed mild memory problems. His medical history is significant for Crohn disease, for which he underwent an ileal resection 10 years ago. On physical examination, he has pale conjunctiva. Neurologic examination shows decreased vibratory and position sense in the lower extremities and a positive Romberg sign. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 10.5 g/dL, a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 115 fL, and a normal serum folate level. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency. His history of ileal resection is a key risk factor, as the terminal ileum is the site of B12 absorption. The deficiency manifests with both hematologic and neurologic findings. The macrocytic anemia (MCV > 100 fL) explains his fatigue and pale conjunctiva. The neurologic symptoms are due to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which involves demyelination of the dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts. This condition leads to loss of proprioception and vibratory sense, resulting in sensory ataxia and a positive Romberg sign. Cognitive impairment is also a recognized feature.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis is a demyelinating disease of the CNS that can cause sensory deficits, balance problems, and cognitive changes. However, it would not cause macrocytic anemia. Additionally, this patient's dorsal column deficits, macrocytic anemia, and history of an ileal resection strongly suggest a different etiology of his clinical features.

C) INCORRECT:

Folate deficiency is a plausible consideration because it also causes macrocytic anemia and can be associated with malabsorptive conditions like Crohn disease. However, the laboratory results explicitly state a normal serum folate level. Furthermore, while folate deficiency can cause some neurologic symptoms like irritability, it does not typically cause the specific dorsal column deficits (loss of vibration and position sense) seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Diabetic neuropathy could explain the numbness and tingling in the feet. However, this patient has no history of diabetes mellitus, and this diagnosis would not explain the macrocytic anemia or the specific findings of decreased vibratory and position sense, which suggest a dorsal column pathology rather than a peripheral nerve length-dependent process alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Anemia of chronic disease is a reasonable consideration due to this patient's history of Crohn disease, an inflammatory condition. This condition can cause fatigue and anemia. However, anemia of chronic disease is typically normocytic and normochromic (or sometimes microcytic), not macrocytic with an MCV of 115 fL. It also does not account for the specific neurologic deficits.
questions.hint: This patient's laboratory findings are consistent with a macrocytic anemia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of balance problems. He follows a vegan diet and does not eat meat, eggs, or dairy. Physical examination shows pale oral mucosa and conjunctivae. Neurologic examination shows normal strength in all extremities and decreased sense to vibration in his lower extremities bilaterally. A peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following enzymes is most likely impaired?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Succinate dehydrogenase is a mitochondrial enzyme that participates in the tricarboxylic acid cycle and uses vitamin B2 (riboflavin) as a cofactor. Riboflavin deficiency is frequently seen in malnourished patients and is characterized by cheilitis, glossitis, gingivostomatitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. Decreased vibratory sense and macrocytic anemia, as seen in this patient, would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

1-Alpha hydroxylase is a key enzyme necessary for the production of the active form of vitamin D. Impaired functioning of this enzyme results in a rare, inherited form of vitamin D deficiency that manifests clinically as rickets. Anemia and neurologic symptoms, as seen in this patient, are not part of the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Propionyl-CoA carboxylase is involved in the conversion of propionyl-CoA to methylmalonyl-CoA and uses biotin as a cofactor. Biotin deficiency could potentially impair propionyl-CoA carboxylase, resulting in accumulation of propionyl-CoA, which can subsequently cause demyelination within the spinal cord. However, this patient's macrocytic anemia and strict vegan diet should raise concern for a different vitamin deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Pyruvate carboxylase participates in amino acid, carbohydrate, and lipid metabolism and uses vitamin B7 (biotin) as a cofactor. Biotin deficiency is relatively rare and is characterized by dermatitis, conjunctivitis, alopecia, and neurologic symptoms. Anemia and decreased vibratory sense are not clinical manifestations of the disorder. A history of antibiotic use or excessive ingestion of raw eggs can result in biotin deficiency; a vegan diet is not a risk factor.

E) CORRECT:

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase requires vitamin B12 as a cofactor in the metabolism of odd-chain fatty acids. In the absence of vitamin B12 (e.g., due to dietary vitamin B12 deficiency), methylmalonyl-CoA and its precursor propionyl-CoA accumulate and subsequently replace acetyl-CoA in neuronal membranes, which results in the demyelination of neurons. This primarily affects the dorsal and lateral columns of the spinal cord and manifests as subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord with symmetric paresthesia, numbness, and decreased proprioception in the lower extremities. Vitamin B12 deficiency also impairs methionine synthase activity, which leads to megaloblastic anemia, pancytopenia, and homocysteinemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Dopamine beta-hydroxylase, which converts dopamine to norepinephrine, uses vitamin C as a cofactor. Vitamin C deficiency results in scurvy, which is a clinical syndrome characterized by hemorrhage, hyperkeratosis, coiled hair, gingivitis, impaired wound healing, and microcytic anemia (as opposed to the macrocytic anemia seen here). Decreased vibratory sensation and a strict vegan diet, as seen in this patient, are not associated with vitamin C deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient's strict vegan diet, impaired vibratory sensation, and macrocytic anemia suggest vitamin B12 deficiency.
